The officer who killed Bradford was placed on administrative leave, while Bradford's family gathered outside the mall Saturday to commemorate him and protest the police shooting. (📸: AP, Facebook)

Terry Rossio, whose work includes Shrek and Disney hits like Aladdin and the Pirates of the Caribbean series, wrote on Twitter, “Anti-Vax is equivalent to calling someone a nigger and makes as little sense.” According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the benefits of vaccination far outweigh any risks, and there is no link between vaccines and autism. (📸: Getty Images)
In an Instagram post, Bieber wrote it was his first Thanksgiving as a married man. Baldwin also posted a photo of the couple kissing, with the caption "very thankful." (📸: Getty Images)
🦁🎥🌟 (📸: Disney)

Intense hurricanes, overharvesting, and the 2010 BP oil spill, along with disease and changes in freshwater flows to Gulf rivers and streams have brought oyster populations to historic lows. "Despite remedial efforts to stem the loss, the decline now seems to be accelerating, and oyster harvests are being further curtailed across the region," according to a new report by the Nature Conservancy. (📷: Getty Images)
Some of the items found in the 31 ft carcass included 115 drinking cups, four plastic bottles, 25 plastic bags and two flip flops. Follow @world for more news from around the 🌏

Some highlights from the trailer are a recreation of the iconic Pride Rock scene, as well as narration from James Earl Jones, returning to play Mufasa. The poster, also released Thursday, shows a young Simba with his little paw inside the pawprint of his father. “The Lion King” will be released July 19, 2019 🦁🎬 (📷: Walt Disney Studios)

Lidia Meza Burgos, 18, was found dead in the cell of Marcelo "Piloto" Pinheiro in Paraguay. She had been beaten and stabbed with a kitchen knife, authorities said. UltimoHora reported it was the second time she had visited the cartel boss, who faces 26 years in jail in Brazil on charges of homicide, arms smuggling, robbery, and drug trafficking. Women in Paraguay are using #JusticiaParaLidia to call for justice and a proper investigation into Meza's murder. (📷: Getty Images)

The White House wants the court to take up three cases challenging its efforts to bar transgender people from serving in the military. If the justices agree to take one or more of the cases, a decision would be expected by June 2019. (📸: Getty Images)

The report, from federal scientists and outside experts, concludes “that the evidence of human-caused climate change is overwhelming and continues to strengthen, that the impacts of climate change are intensifying across the country, and that climate-related threats to Americans’ physical, social, and economic well-being are rising.” (📸: Reuters)

Emily Koziel, a 20-year-old student at Michigan State University, lives with three roommates. Their cat, Otto, is so bossy that he regularly gets multiple meals a day by convincing people he's hungry. They hope the new chart will keep them from getting tricked (and help Otto slim down). (📸: Emily Koziel)
In the '00s, Black Friday wasn't just a shopping holiday — it was a blood sport. (📸: Getty)

Survivors of the deadly California Camp fire were able to enjoy a moment of respite in the form of a warm Thanksgiving meal, thanks to acts of kindness by volunteers, nonprofit organizations, and fellow residents. The Northern California wildfire— the deadliest in the state’s history — has killed 83 people, injured three firefighters, and burned more than 18,000 structures. More than 500 people still remain unaccounted for after the fire, which is contained at 90%. (📸: AP, Getty)

Trump has revealed what he is thankful for this Thanksgiving: his “great family” and the “tremendous impact” he says he has had on the country. “This country is so much stronger now than it was when I took office and you wouldn’t believe it and when you see it," Trump told the press at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida, which he said he has dubbed the “Southern Winter White House.” When asked who should be blamed for killing of Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi, Trump said “maybe the world” because it’s a “vicious, vicious place.” He then visited a Coast Guard station before being dropped off at Trump International Golf Course. (📸: AP)

John Chau was shot and killed by arrows while attempting to reach the remote Sentinelese tribe in the Andaman Islands in India to teach them about Jesus Christ, a mission he told friends about 2 years ago. Chau's friend, John Middleton Ramsey, told BuzzFeed News he was sad to hear about Chau's death, but said “It’s not like I was like completely surprised. I had known about his plans and I knew about the dangers.” Ramsey also said Chau knew visiting the island was illegal. Chau had made a “scouting” trip to the Andaman Islands to make contacts with local Christians two years ago: "He had a passion for reaching them with Christ," Ramsey said. “I encouraged him and said if that’s what God is calling him to do, then I was very much behind it.” Ramsey says he hopes his friend is "remembered as a martyr. Someone who put his faith first and was willing to die for it." (📸: AP, John Chau)
It was 19 degrees in New York, but Kelly Clarkson refused to lip-sync, telling parade officials that "I sing live" before performing "Heat." (📸: NBC / Getty Images)
The new balloons in the parade, which took place in New York City in 19-degree weather, included Goku from the Dragon Ball series. (📸: Getty Images)

Minnesota police arrested Lloyd Edward Johnson, 55, of Eden Prairie after a cell phone video of Johnson allegedly pulling a gun on a group of black Somali Muslim teens went viral on Twitter. (📸: Eden Prairie Police Department / Hennepin County Corrections / Farida Osman)

Gap plans to close hundreds of Gap-brand stores that are "dragging down the brand," the company said. The retailer currently has 775 Gap-brand specialty stores globally, which have been lagging as its Old Navy and Athleta brands grow. Cutting off languishing stores could add over $100 million in earnings, Gap said. (📷: AP)

“You can get in trouble with your husband sometimes over too many photos like that,” she said on “The Ellen Show.” The mom of three said her rapper husband can be bothered by the photos, but he is also supportive. “It’s like half and half,” she said. “He always wants me to be me and feel confident and we’re having fun, but it also bothers him.” (📸: @kimkardashian/ Getty Images)

John Allen Chau, a US citizen who was reported missing after traveling to North Sentinel Island as a Christian missionary, was shot and killed by arrows from a remote tribe after he tried to illegally approach and befriend them. The Sentinelese tribe are the only occupants of the island and remain completely disconnected from the outside world. It is illegal to visit there. Chau was taken to the island by a group of fisherman, who said they last saw him alive on Nov. 16, and the next day "saw a dead body being dragged and getting buried" near the shore. The fishermen have since been arrested, but it is unlikely the Sentinelese, will face any charges. Police say they are trying to recover Chau's body. (📸: AP, John Chau)

Andrew Sipowicz was irritated when he found his car damaged – until he saw the note from a sixth grader who described – and illustrated – the accident in detail. The note says that Sopowicz's car was hit by a school bus that then took off. "Shoutout to the anonymous 6th grader for saving me a couple thousand (Bus not drawn to scale)," he tweeted. The bus company said that it met with Sipowicz and will "cover the full cost of the repair" for damage done by the former driver. They also thanked the anonymous artist: "We would be remiss if we didn’t mention that we are very impressed by this exceptional sixth grader." (📸: Andrew Sipowicz)

Minaj was scheduled to perform at an event called the Djakarta Warehouse Project festival in Shanghai on Nov. 18, according to Shanghaiist. Djakarta Warehouse Project is an annual dance festival in Indonesia, and this Shanghai event was billed as its Chinese spin-off. But as it turns out, the use of the DWP brand by the concert in China was "unauthorized," according to a statement from DWP International that appeared on the event's website days before the event was set to begin. (📸: Getty)

About 72% of students at the private Asheville Waldorf School, a private school in Asheville, North Carolina, were not vaccinated for chickenpox due to religious exemptions, health officials said. (📸: Getty Images)

Instagram users have noticed their Explore page has been involuntarily reset to include a lot of content they’re not interested in. It seems the apparent glitch is not affecting all users, but a spokesperson for Facebook, Instagram’s parent company, told BuzzFeed News that there were issues with features across the “Facebook family of apps” and that they were working to “resolve the issue ASAP.” 📲🤔 (📷: Getty Images)

Ivanka Trump used a private email account during her first six months working for the White House, a time when President Trump continued to call for his 2016 rival Hillary Clinton to be locked up over her private email use. She exchanged hundreds of emails with White House aides, officials, and her assistants, the Washington Post reported. 📧👀 (📷: AP)

Lou Anna Simon, 59, was charged with four counts of lying to a peace officer about her knowledge of Larry Nassar and prior investigations into a sexual assault complaint against him. In 2014, MSU graduate Amanda Thomashow was inappropriately touched by Nassar after she went to him for help with hip pain. Thomashow filed a complaint to police and the university about Nassar's behavior, and a Title IX investigation cleared Nassar of any misconduct. Simon later told police she "was aware that in 2014 there was a sports medicine doc who was subject to a review." But in new court documents filed Tuesday, the Michigan Attorney General's office asserts that Simon knew that Nassar was the target of the investigation (📷: Getty)

So far, 32 people in 11 states have gotten sick. An additional 18 cases have been seen in Canada. No one has died during the outbreak, according to the CDC, but five people died in a larger outbreak of E. coli linked to romaine lettuce earlier this year. E. coli O157:H7 is particularly hazardous because it can produce a toxin that causes severe, sometimes bloody, diarrhea and a condition called hemolytic uremic syndrome, which can lead to kidney failure. (📷: Getty Images)
BuzzFeed News totes are here 😍 Get one in our bio

Dr. Tamara O’Neal, 38, was one of the three people killed by a gunman at Mercy Hospital in Chicago. According to multiple reports, O’Neal and the gunman were due to be married earlier this year. A Chicago police officer and a first-year pharmacy resident were also killed in the shooting. (📸: Getty Images/Twitter)
"I want to thank me for believing in me. I want to thank me for doing all this hard work....Snoop Dogg you a bad motherfucker," the West Coast rapper said during the ceremony 🎶⭐️ (📷: Getty Images)

Chicago police said a gunman shot and killed a woman, an employee of Mercy Hospital, who “he was in a domestic relationship with.” The shooter then fled into the hospital, where he exchanged gunfire with officers. During the exchange, another female employee was fatally shot, as well as Chicago Police officer Samuel Jimenez, who joined the force last year in February. The gunman was also killed. (📷:AP/Getty Images)

Journalist James Andrew Miller revealed on his Origins podcast that, after talking to “Sex and the City” creator Michael Patrick King, Sarah Jessica Parker, Cynthia Nixon, and Kristin Davis, the plan for “Sex and the City 3” was to have Mr. Big die of a heart attack in the shower early on in the film. Miller also spoke to sources close to Kim Cattrall who said she was put off by the plot detail. Miller’s sources said “the remainder of the movie [was] more about how Carrie recovers from Big’s death than about the relationship between the four women,” meaning the script “didn’t have a lot to offer the character of Samantha.” (📷: HBO)

Christopher Watts, 33, pleaded guilty to murder in November in a deal with prosecutors to avoid the death penalty for killing his wife, 34-year-old Shanann Watts, and their two daughters, 3-year-old Celeste and 4-year-old Bella. Watts also pleaded guilty at the time to unlawful termination of a pregnancy, as Shanann was pregnant with a boy when she was killed. In the courtroom, Watts hung his head as his former father-in-law Frank Rzucek spoke before his sentencing. “You may have taken their bodies from me but you will never take the love they had for me,” Rzucek said. (📷: AP/Getty)

One of Katie Bower’s sons turned six this week, so she posted on her Instagram to mark his birthday. The message started out pretty normal, with Bower discussing what she loved about him, but then things took a turn for the worst. Bower wrote about how her son's photos never got "as many likes" as her other photos, and how she had struggled with that for years. She blamed the lower engagement on everything from Instagram's algorithm, to him being lost as a middle child, to his "squinty eyes.” She then asked her followers to give him likes for his birthday. The post has since been archived. (📷: @bowerpowerblog)

The rapper, whose real name is Daniel Hernandez, was arrested along with Kifano "Shotti" Jordan, Jensel "Ish" Butler, and Faheem "Crippy" Walter, according to a spokesperson for the US Attorney's Office. His arrest was the result of a joint investigation by Homeland Security Investigations, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, and New York police. Hernandez, 22, may be facing jail time for violating probation on an unrelated charge. (📷: Getty)
YouTube quietly started streaming free ad-supported feature-length films on the service back in October. (📸: Getty Images / Type A Films)
Is this iPhone trick new to you or were you already doing it? 📱🤯

After being displaced by the Camp fire in Northern California, almost a thousand people have set up makeshift housing in a Walmart parking lot. These photos show the limited facilities on offer for families left sitting in the still-smoky air, trying to figure out what comes next. (📷: Joel Angel Juárez)

Falconers across Egypt gathered in the Borg al-Arab desert to celebrate World Falconry Day on Saturday. The event, now in its sixth year, aims to increase awareness of the sport and help preserve the ancient tradition of falconry 🇪🇬🦅 Follow @world for more news from around the 🌎(📷: Reuters)

The donation, which is believed to be the largest private sum donated to a US college in the modern era, will be used to ensure the school is "forever need-blind," meaning that any student who achieves the requisite grades can attend the school, regardless of financial status. The billionaire said he was only able to attend Johns Hopkins in his youth due to a National Defense student loan and a college job. "My Hopkins diploma opened up doors that otherwise would have been closed, and allowed me to live the American dream," Bloomberg wrote in a New York Times op-ed announcing the donation to his alma mater 🎓💰 (📷: Flickr/Getty)

Florida Gov. Rick Scott has won the close and tense Florida race for US Senate over the incumbent, Sen. Bill Nelson, after a hand recount ended on Sunday. The official results put Scott, a Republican, up 50.05% to 49.93% over Nelson, a Democrat. That represents a difference of about 10,000 votes in a race where well over 8 million people voted. (📷: Getty Images)

“For the last three days I’ve been trying to wake up out of this nightmare. But I haven’t. I don’t know what I’m going to do without you baby,” Diddy wrote under a video of the two of them over the years. Porter was found dead in her LA home after reportedly recently experiencing flu-like symptoms. She was the mother of the three children they had together. (📷: @diddy)

The former vice president and his wife Jill have been fostering Major and adopted him from the Delaware Humane Association on Saturday. Major came to the shelter as a puppy and needless to say, he already has tons of fans on the internet. Welcome home, Major 🐶😍 (📷: @delawarehumane)
Reminder: Never give honey to babies younger than 12 months because of the risk of botulism, a potentially life-threatening condition. (📸: Getty Images)

After evacuating the catastrophic Camp fire in Northern California, at least 145 people in four shelters have been sickened with norovirus, a gastrointestinal illness that causes intense diarrhea and vomiting, officials said. (📷: AP)

A flight attendant for Philippine Airlines Express, said she breastfed a passenger’s baby during a flight earlier this month after she heard the baby crying and found out that the baby’s mother had run out of formula milk👶🍼❤️ Follow @world for more headlines from across the 🌏
Smoke from the fires has made the air hazardous to breathe in many areas, particularly in Northern California ⚠️ (📷: Getty Images, AP)

The dolphin was likely shot at sea before it floated to shore, said animal welfare worker Peter Wallerstein. He said he’s seen several sea lions shot (by people on fishing boats who think the animals are interfering with the fishing, he believes), but that he can’t remember ever finding a shot dolphin. The Marine Animal Rescue Group is offering a $5,000 reward for information leading to the conviction of the dolphin killer. (📷: Marine Animal Rescue)

Erika Hilton and Erica Malunguinho share a radical vision for their country that centers on empowering other Afro-Brazilians. They’re the first trans women to be elected to São Paulo’s influential state legislature, and were elected just weeks before Jair Bolsanaro, known as Brazil’s Donald Trump, was elected on the back of racist, sexist, and anti-gay rhetoric. “Do not stop looking at Brazil,” Hilton said. “We are going through a collapse.” (📷: Patricia Montiero for BuzzFeed News)

The number of people reported unaccounted for in the California wildfires has skyrocketed to 1,011, and the death toll has risen to 74. The number of victims continues to rise as search and recovery teams comb through charred homes and cars in the town of Paradise in Northern California. Officials warned that the number of unaccounted for is compiled from 911 calls after the fire broke out, as well as calls to a missing persons hotline, and there may be duplicates. The fire is now 50% contained, but firefighters expect to face challenges over the weekend with a new red flag warning in effect. (📸: Getty)

Nicholas Godejohn was found guilty of murder and sentenced to life without parole in the killing of his ex-girlfriend Gypsy Rose Blanchard's mother, Claudine "Dee Dee" Blanchard, who spent years convincing the world that her daughter suffered from a myriad of debilitating diseases. Godejohn and Gypsy Rose were secretly dating in June 2015 when he stabbed her mother 17 times at the family's Missouri home. Friends initially believed Gypsy suffered from mental deficits, muscular dystrophy, a seizure disorder, and cancer, and were worried when she couldn't be found after her mother's murder, but it was soon revealed that Gypsy Rose wasn't sick at all, and her mother had invented her lifelong ailments in what is believed to have been Munchausen syndrome by proxy. Gypsy Rose, who realized at 19 that she was healthy, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder and is serving a 10-year prison sentence. (📸: Andrew Jansen)

“I acknowledge that Brian Kemp will be certified as the victor in the 2018 gubernatorial election," Stacey Abrams said. "But to watch an elected official who claims to represent the people in this state baldly pin his hopes for election on the suppression of the people's democratic right to vote has been truly appalling." Kemp until recently was Georgia's secretary of state, during which his office held over 53,000 voter registration applications — predominantly from black voters — for what it called voter roll maintenance. Abrams refused to call her statement a traditional concession, but acknowledged that she has limited legal options to proceed. (📸: Getty Images)

Under the Department of Education’s proposed regulations, schools must let an accused person cross-examine their accuser through a third party, will be able to use a higher standard of evidence to decide an accused student’s guilt, and will not have to investigate reports of off-campus sexual assaults involving students. Victim advocacy groups say the changes are designed to give schools an excuse to ignore sexual misconduct on campuses. The Trump administration estimates the regulations will save schools nationwide over $286 million over 10 years by having fewer cases to investigate. (📷: Getty)

Allyn Pierce, a nurse, evacuated his hospital and its patients by literally driving through the fire. All around him, vehicles started bursting into flames and some people — with few options on blocked roads — began to climb out and run. At one point, Pierce recorded a message on his phone for his wife and two kids, just in case. And after all that, he returned to the hospital, where he and other first responders continued to treat the injured in a makeshift triage while the fire raged around them. “If we were going to die today we would at least do it protecting others and do everything we can to live and we did!” wrote Tamara Ferguson, another nurse. (📷: @the_pandra/Getty)

The remains of seven additional victims of the Camp fire have been recovered, bringing the death toll from the blaze to 63. As of Thursday, exactly one week since the fire broke out, 631 remain unaccounted for, Butte County Sheriff-Coroner Kory Honea said. He encouraged people to check the department's list of those who have not yet been found and contact the department if their name or a loved one who has been accounted for is on the list. Three other deaths have been linked to the Woolsey fire, which hit Malibu and surrounding areas particularly hard. (📷: Getty Images)

The cofounder of BenShot, a Wisconsin-based glassware company, told BuzzFeed News he wanted to give the gift of "personal protection to keep employees safe." So they decided to give each employee a gift card for the amount of $500 toward any local gun supply shop of their choice. Each employee will need to pass a background check and take a basic training course on handgun safety and protocol before redeeming it for an actual gun. (📷: BenShot)

Last November, Katelyn McClure said a homeless man, Johnny Bobbitt Jr., used his last $20 to help when her car ran out of gas on a busy Philadelphia interstate. The heartwarming story went viral, and her boyfriend, Mark D’Amico, launched a GoFundMe campaign for Bobbitt, which attracted over 14,000 donors. Now, police say the trio concocted the whole story to scam people into donating over $400,000. They have all been charged with second-degree theft by deception and conspiracy to commit theft by deception. (📷: GoFundMe/Burlington County Prosecutor’s Office)

Kim Porter, 47, was reportedly found dead at her Los Angeles home after experiencing flu-like symptoms. Porter was an actor and in an on-again off-again relationship with Diddy from 1994 until 2007. "Sadly, I can confirm the passing of Kim Porter. I ask that you give the families privacy at this time,” a representative for Diddy said. She leaves behind four children. (📷: Getty images)

A federal judge this morning sided with Democrats who challenged a signature matching policy that left thousands of Florida voters’ ballots uncounted. Those voters will now have another chance for their ballots to be counted in close races amid a statewide recount. (📷: Getty Images)

Miles Scott, the boy who stole everyone's hearts as a 5-year-old Leukemia patient when he took over San Francisco as Batkid in 2013, has been in remission for five years, Make-A-Wish has announced. Scott is now 10 years old and has reached the important milestone, which for many is the point when someone can be considered cancer free. Scott is now in fifth grade, and loves science and robotics. He also plays in the Little League, and helps his family on their farm — recently selling his first market goat at the local fair 🧡🎗(📷: AP)

Iz and Colleen knew they wanted to incorporate some feline fun into their wedding. Since their own cats are older rescues with health issues, they offered guests a kitten hour, instead of a cocktail hour, complete with six adorable kittens from the Seattle Animal Shelter. The couple donated to the shelter before the wedding, and say it was cheaper than a cocktail hour and a huge hit with guests. The kittens were selected for their social temperament and were only at the wedding for an hour, with volunteers making sure they were handled safely. All six have since found their furever homes 🐱❤️ (📸: @fuckyeahweddings)

Women in Ireland are protesting after a defense lawyer held up a 17-year-old girl’s underwear in court during a rape trial, and said “You have to look at the way she was dressed. She was wearing a thong with a lace front.” A 27-year-old man was later found not guilty of raping the teenager. Outraged demonstrators built on an online movement using #ThisIsNotConsent after the trial, prompting hundreds of women to tweet photos of their underwear and call the use of underwear in court “victim blaming.” (📸: Getty Images)

Michael Avenatti, the attorney representing porn actor Stormy Daniels in her legal pursuit of President Trump, has been arrested on suspicion of domestic violence in Los Angeles, police confirmed. Avenatti had not yet been booked, but a report on the alleged incident was taken on Tuesday, Los Angeles police said. (📸: AP)

Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke called the Camp fire, which practically destroyed the town of Paradise in Northern California, "worse than any war zone I saw in Iraq." California Gov. Jerry Brown echoed Zinke's assessment, saying he barely had the words to describe the destruction. The Camp fire has killed 48 people and burned 8,800 structures, making it the most deadly and destructive in the state's history. Butte County officials also posted a preliminary list of dozens of people still missing in the fire. Three other people have died so far in the Woolsey fire. (📸: Getty Images)

This is El Jefe, whose owner works at a sex shop near a Little Caesars in Mexico City. He's so good at begging for pizza, he now has to wear a tag to keep tourists from giving him a slice 🐶🍕(📸: Facebook)

The two letters, found on different days, said “You’re a terrorist” and “I will kill you.” “It’s pretty disgusting,” the girl’s uncle told local TV station Boston 25. “Threatening a child for no apparent reason.” (📸: Boston 25)
"The library connects us with the insight and knowledge, painfully extracted from Nature, of the greatest minds that ever were.” ― Carl Sagan (📸: Getty Images)

Emma Hallberg, a 19-year-old self-described model and “influencer,” has been accused by some of her followers of pretending to be black after an older photo showing her with a lighter skin tone was circulated online. Many people said they felt deceived by how the teen presented herself in her photos. Hallberg has even been accused of literally painting on a different skin color when she applies her makeup, and intentionally darkening her skin significantly. Hallberg denied to BuzzFeed News she used any self-tanners or spray tans, stating she has never “claimed or tried to be black or anything else.” “I do not see myself as anything else than white,” she said. “I get a deep tan naturally from the sun.” (📷: @eemmahallberg, supplied)

Netflix has announced that Cardi B, T.I., and Chance the Rapper will act as judges on the service's upcoming music competition show, “Rhythm + Flow.” The superstars are tasked with helping undiscovered hip-hop artists pursue their dreams. Auditions for the show will begin this fall in the US, including in each of the judges' hometowns of Atlanta, Chicago, and New York ✨🎤 (📷: Getty)

Wildfires across California have caused widespread damage and forced thousands to flee their homes. At least 42 people have died in what is now the deadliest wildfire in California history. Follow @buzzfeedphoto for more 📸(📷: Getty, Reuters, AP)

Bias-motivated attacks against black people, Jews, Muslims, LGBT people, and other minorities all saw sharp increases or other concerning patterns. "This is a historic increase, and it has to be recognized as such," said  Brian Levin, director of the Center for the Study of Hate and Extremism at California State University, San Bernardino. (📸: Getty Images)
The NRA told doctors advocating for gun control to "stay in their lane." Medical professionals responded by sharing photos and stories of what their life is like dealing with victims of gun violence.
The end is coming ⚔❄ (📸: HBO)

Amazon is splitting the site of its second headquarters, dubbed HQ2, between the two locations. Hundreds of cities competed for the estimated $5 billion project by offering the tech giant steep tax subsidies and other incentives. (📸: Getty Images)

Democrat Kyrsten Sinema, the first openly bisexual person elected to Congress, has defeated Republican Martha McSally to win a US Senate race in Arizona, narrowly flipping a seat long held by Republicans in a come-from-behind victory one week after Election Day. It’s the first time Arizona has elected a woman to the Senate in its 106-year history. (📷: Getty Images)

The Tide Eco-Box has been designed "to reduce the environmental impact of shipping laundry detergent in eCommerce," a Procter & Gamble spokesperson said. While this is all great for e-commerce and (sensible) consumers, people are joking that the new packaging will make it "so much more convenient" to consume laundry detergent... and that they've basically marketed it as boxed detergent wine 🍷🤢 (📷: Procter & Gamble)

In Northern California, the Camp fire has scorched more than 6,700 structures, making it the most destructive in California history. At least 29 people died as the inferno swept into the town of Paradise, making it the third-deadliest fire in the state's history. Two additional deaths have been linked to the Woolsey fire in Malibu. Across the state, officials are urging residents to stay alert and heed evacuation orders for their safety. (📷: Getty Images)

💥 Always surrounded by the colorful characters he helped create, here are some highlights from the life of the comic writer and film producer, who died Monday at 95. (📷: Alamy/AP/Getty/Everett Collection/Reuters)
The comic writer and film producer was best known for co-creating iconic superheroes like Spider-Man, the Hulk, X-Men, and Black Panther. He was 95. (📸: Washington Post/Getty Images)

“The vibrant diversity of the two previous inaugurations was gone,” the former first lady wrote in her memoir “Becoming.” “Someone from Barack’s administration might have said that the optics there were bad — that what the public saw didn’t reflect the president’s reality or ideals. But in this case, maybe it did. Realizing it, I made my own optic adjustment: I stopped even trying to smile.” (📸: Getty Images)

Seven ancient tombs containing mummified cats have been discovered in the Egyptian village of Saqqara, southeast of Cairo. The tombs are believed to be from the pharaonic age Fifth Dynasty of the Old Kingdom, and they can be dated back 6,000 years. Cats were beloved by the ancient Egyptians, who worshipped the goddess Bastet, who is often depicted as a cat. (📷: Reuters)

Juul Labs decided to stop selling most of its flavored nicotine pods at brick-and-mortar retail stores, according to the Wall Street Journal. Its flavored liquid pods, including cucumber and mango, will instead be sold on its website, which has age-verification tools that bar purchases by people under 21 years old. (📷: Getty Images)

RuPaul came under fire last year for saying he would “probably not” allow a transitioning transgender woman to compete. But the new season will feature fan favorite Gia Gunn, who came out as trans and began hormone replacement therapy after appearing in the sixth season. “If you’re a fierce queen and you bring it to the runway you should be accepted as one and nothing more and nothing less,” she said 🏳️‍🌈 (📷: Getty Images/VH1)

Proponents of repealing the tax have argued that tampons and pads are a necessity for about half the population at some point in their lives, and should be treated (and taxed) as an essential item, not a luxury item. Other medically necessary items like bandages (and items like groceries, candy, and soda) had already been exempt from the state’s 6.85% tax rate. (📷: Getty)

Women participated in nearly every aspect of the war effort: manufacturing and agricultural roles, switchboard operators and couriers, ambulance drivers, doctors, and nurses, to name a few jobs. On the occasion of the World War I armistice centennial, here’s a look back at the incredible women who fought and won the war. (📸: Getty Images)

Three major wildfires are raging in California, scorching tens of thousands of acres and forcing entire cities to evacuate. At least nine people have died as a result of the Camp fire in Northern California, while officials confirmed the first two officials linked to the devastating Woolsey Fire in Southern California, which has forced the entire city of Malibu to evacuate. A total of 174,531 acres have burned, 272,000 people have been evacuated, and more than 5,000 firefighters are battling the blazes. President Trump offered no condolences to those killed in the California wildfires, but did in a tweet Saturday cast blame for the blazes on “gross mismanagement of the forests.” Trump said “billions of dollars are given each year,” and threatened “no more Fed payments” if it isn’t improved. (📸: Getty)

State election officials ordered a statewide machine recount in three tight Florida races Saturday. Florida law requires a machine recount when a race’s margin reaches 0.5%, and a recount by hand is necessary when the margin is less than 0.25%. The Florida Division of Elections reported two big races inside that margin: the Senate race that shows Republican Gov. Rick Scott 0.15% ahead of incumbent Sen. Bill Nelson, and the governor’s race results showing Republican Ron DeSantis 0.41% ahead of Democrat Andrew Gillum, who had already conceded. A point of growing contention was whether ballots counted by county officials for the first time Saturday afternoon could be considered in the recount, thereby changing the election's final outcome. Under Florida law, noon marked deadline for election local boards to submit unofficial results to the Florida Division of Elections. Trump accused Democrats of "trying to steal" the two elections after the recount was announced. The recount results are due to the state by 3 p.m. Nov. 15. (📸: Getty)
✨☂️🇬🇧 (📸: Getty Images/Vogue)

The curriculum is intended to address bullying, discrimination, and prejudice in schools and will be mandatory for all public schools by 2021. “Our education system must support everyone to reach their full potential,” Deputy First Minister John Swinney said in a statement. “That is why it is vital the curriculum is as diverse as the young people who learn in our schools.” 🌈🏴󠁧󠁢󠁳󠁣󠁴󠁿 (📸: Getty Images)
At least nine people have been killed and thousands of structures destroyed as wildfires in California force people — and animals — to seek shelter. (📸: @latimes via Getty Images/AFP/Getty Images/AP)

Fires in Southern California have prompted entire cities to evacuate and scorched thousands of acres. Kim Kardashian West tweeted Thursday night that she had flown back to California only to have to pack up her home in Calabasas due to the fire. Kanye West later tweeted that they had evacuated, but TMZ reported that the Woolsey fire had reached their home. Kim's sister Khloe also tweeted that she and her daughter had evacuated, as did Lady Gaga, Jake Paul, Alyssa Milano, Rainn Wilson, Cher, and other celebrities. The Woolsey fire was just one of three major wildfires raging across the state on Friday, including the Hill fire, also in Southern California, and the Camp fire in Northern California, which has killed at least 9 people. (📸: Getty)

The man who opened fire inside a bar in Southern California killing 12 people posted on Instagram during the massacre that he hoped people would call him “insane” and said that he “had no reason to do it,” officials confirmed to BuzzFeed News. The shooter, 28-year-old Ian David Long, first posted on Instagram at 11:24 p.m., and again at 11:27 p.m., according to ABC News. Officials said the first report of gunfire at the Borderline Bar & Grill came in at 11:19 p.m. and that deputies arrived in three minutes, entering the building at 11:25 p.m. “I hope people call me insane,” Long wrote in one post. "The only thing you people do after these shootings is ‘hopes and prayers’... or ‘keep you in my thoughts’... every time... and wonder why these keep happening.” (📸: AP)

The CDC is warning consumers about a deadly outbreak of salmonella linked to raw turkey after one person died in California and 164 others were sickened. The outbreak now spans 35 states. Laboratory evidence indicates that various raw turkey products (including ground turkey, turkey patties, and turkey pieces) are contaminated with Salmonella Reading, a type of bacteria that can infect the gastrointestinal tract. People who have gotten sick have reported eating various types of turkey products sold under different brands and purchased from multiple locations — so no single source or supplier has been identified. The CDC says people don't need to stop eating turkey, but should take caution when handling raw turkey products, wash their hands and any food preparation surfaces, thaw turkey in the fridge instead of leaving it on the counter to defrost, and make sure the internal temperature when cooking reaches 165 degrees Fahrenheit. (📸: Getty)

Three wildfires are raging in California, scorching thousands of acres and forcing entire cities to evacuate. At least five people died in their vehicles torched by the Camp fire in the Northern California city of Paradise, where at least 20,000 acres have been scorched. Less than 24 hours after a mass shooting in Thousand Oaks, more than 200,000 residents in Southern California have had to flee their homes as the Woolsey fire and the Hill fire tore though the region. The entire city of Malibu was forced to evacuate due to the wind-driven Woolsey fire. California’s Governor-elect Gavin Newsom has declared a state of emergency in Butte County in Northern California as well as in Ventura and Los Angeles Counties in Southern California. (📸: AP)

“I felt lost and alone and I felt like I failed because I didn’t know how common miscarriages were because we don’t talk about it. We sit in our own pain thinking that somehow we’re broken," Obama said on "Good Morning America" while discussing her upcoming memoir, "Becoming." In the book, Obama explains that she and Barack Obama dealt with infertility and used in vitro fertilization to conceive their children. (📷: Getty)

Fans of Ruth Bader Ginsburg can breathe a sigh of relief: The Supreme Court justice is out of the hospital and getting back to work. Ginsburg — who, at 85, is the oldest member of the top US court — fractured three ribs during a fall in her office on Wednesday night. (📷: Getty)

The shooting at Borderline Bar & Grill shocked the community of Thousand Oaks, which touted its status as one of the safest cities in the US. On Wednesday, the bar was hosting College Country Night — a night of dancing open to anyone 18 and over that drew crowds of local country music fans. Victims included the first law enforcement officer who tried to stop the gunman, bar employees, and college students. (📷: Facebook/Instagram)

"I have two words: gun control," Susan Orfanos told BuzzFeed News. "Now, now, now, now. No more NRA. No more money. Gun control now." Orfanos' son Telemachus was one of 12 people killed in the Thousand Oaks mass shooting. He had attended the Route 91 Harvest music festival in Las Vegas last year, surviving the deadliest mass shooting in modern US history. "I don't want prayers. I don't want thoughts," his mother said. "I want gun control.” (📸: Facebook)

“I talked to him last night before he headed out the door," Jason Coffman said of his son Cody, 22. "First thing I said was 'Please don't drink and drive.' The last thing I said was 'Son, I love you.'" Cody was one of 12 people shot and killed in the Thousand Oaks mass shooting. “I cannot believe that it has happened to my family," Jason Coffman said. "I am speechless and heartbroken." Between 10 and 15 additional people were injured in the shooting, and the suspect, a 28-year-old Marine veteran, was found dead inside the bar. (📸: Getty)

When Helus entered the California bar, he immediately exchanged gunfire with the suspect and was shot several times, Ventura County Sheriff Geoff Dean said at a press conference. "Ron was a hardworking, dedicated sheriff sergeant," Dean said. "He was totally committed. He gave it his all, and tonight, as I told his wife, he died a hero because he went in to save lives, to save other people." He was due to retire next year. (📸: Ventura County Sheriff / Facebook)

Ginsburg fractured three ribs after falling in her office, officials said. She went home on Wednesday night, but after experiencing pain she went to George Washington University Hospital on Thursday morning. (📸: AP)

The gunman opened fire late Wednesday at Borderline Bar & Grill in Thousand Oaks, which was holding its country music college night. The suspect was also found dead. Between 10 and 15 additional people were injured in the shooting and transported to hospitals, the Ventura County sheriff said. (📸: AP)

The decision to revoke the correspondent’s credentials came after he refused to give up a microphone while asking a question of President Trump. Video from the exchange showed a woman attempting to take the microphone from Acosta, who says, "Pardon me, ma'am," after briefly making contact with her arm. Acosta then continues to ask a question about the Russia investigation, which Trump doesn't answer. White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said the decision to revoke Acosta's credentials was made because of his "placing hands on a young woman just trying to do her job as a White House intern." Acosta said Sanders's description of what happened was a lie, and in a statement, CNN agreed. (📷: Reuters)

“If you look at, for example, Meredith Grey and Derek Shepherd through the lens of Time’s Up and #MeToo, he was her boss, she was an intern, and she kept saying, ‘No, walk away from me,’ and he kept pursuing her,” showrunner Krista Vernoff said. “And that is probably not a story we would tell on the show today, and it’s a rare beautiful reflection of the changing times.” 👨‍⚕️👩‍⚕️📺 (📷: ABC)

A voter named Rashaud was disgusted when he saw the man wearing a T-shirt with a Confederate flag, the image of a noose, and the words “Mississippi Justice” on it, so he began taking pictures. “When I saw him I wanted to say something, but my mom was like, ‘Don’t say anything,’ so I took a picture and posted it on Facebook,” Rashaud told BuzzFeed News. “It just shocks me that people feel it’s OK to come out in public like this. I was just kind of shook up,” he said. As the photo spread, people began identifying the man as Clayton John Hickey, a registered nurse who works at a hospital in Memphis. (📷: Supplied)

Republican Steve West whose son and daughter publicly urged people not to vote for their father because he is "racist" and "homophobic" has lost his election to the state's house.“I can’t imagine him being in any level of government,” Emily West reportedly said of her father. “He’s made multiple comments that are racist and homophobic and how he doesn’t like the Jews.” West had a long history of bigotry, particularly on his radio show and YouTube channel.(📷: YouTube)

Sessions submitted his resignation to President Trump on Wednesday, saying he did so at the president’s request. Trump has repeatedly criticized Sessions to reporters and on Twitter after Sessions recused himself from the Department of Justice’s investigation into Russian influence in the 2016 election. (📷: AP)

Ariana Grande dropped her STUNNING music video for “Breathin,” off her “Sweetener” album today. Just this week she released her newest single, “Thank U, Next,” which was inspired by her breakup with Pete Davidson 🖤(📷: YouTube)

Dennis Hof, a pimp turned Trump-inspired Republican candidate for the Nevada State Assembly, died last month — but it was too late to take his name off the ballot. So what happens next? Under Nevada law, if a candidate who is deceased is elected, the rules are the same as if the person died in office: The county commissioners appoint someone who is in the same party as the deceased to fill the seat.

Michigan voters puff, puff, passed a measure to legalize marijuana on Tuesday, joining a wave of states breaking away from federal prohibition amid a seemingly unstoppable surge of public support to let adults use, buy, and sell the drug in peace. Over in North Dakota, voters rejected their own legalization measure 💨 (📷: AP)

More than 100 women candidates won races for Congress and governor Tuesday night, and many more won local races. Next year, a record number of women candidates, most of them Democrats, will be in Congress. They were a key part of Democrats taking the majority in the House. (📷: Reuters/Getty)

Trump called House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi to "extend his congratulations on winning a Democratic House Majority," Pelosi's spokesperson said. In a victory widely seen as a rebuke to Trump, Democrats won in many longtime Republican strongholds that had flipped to Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election and where the president remained historically unpopular. (📷: Getty)

Beto O'Rourke mounted an impressive challenge to GOP incumbent Ted Cruz, who had a clear advantage in Texas, but it wasn't enough. So when the result became clear, memes flowed from both Texans and non-Texans alike.

Kim Davis, the county clerk in rural Kentucky who became a conservative celebrity for refusing to issue marriage licenses after the Supreme Court’s 2015 landmark marriage ruling, was ejected from office on Tuesday night as voters chose her Democratic rival. (📷: AP)

Michigan Democrat Rashida Tlaib has won her election after running unopposed by a Republican, becoming the first Muslim woman ever elected to Congress. She’s among 100 or more Muslims who ran for office in 2018, an unprecedented surge in political engagement for a community targeted by policies intended to keep them on the sidelines. (📷: AP)

Charlie Matthews, 73, presented Stacey Abrams with roses on behalf of the women in his family who have died and could not witness the progress the candidate has made thus far, the Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported. Abrams could be the first black woman ever elected as governor in the country's history 💐 (📷: AP)

In what has now become an Election Day tradition, voters paid tribute to Susan B. Anthony by placing their "I voted" stickers on her grave. Back in 1872, Anthony voted illegally in the presidential election to protest women being unable to cast ballots. A leading voice in the Suffragette movement, she was charged and fined for her attempt to vote. Anthony died in 1906, 14 years before the passage of the 19th Amendment, which allowed women the right to vote in the US. (📷: @hotrodbetties)

The singer shared a series of photos on Instagram wearing a "Beto for Senate" hat less than three hours before polls closed. “We can’t voice our frustrations and complain about what’s wrong without voting and exercising our power to make it right," Beyonce wrote. O'Rourke is running against Republican incumbent Ted Cruz. (📷: @beyonce)

When BuzzFeed News spoke with Larry Schweikart about his baseless tweet, he said he's not concerned whether the information is true or false. "Well, it’s just a report. Hey, fake news, right?" (📸: PatriotsHistoryUSA.com)

Agents canceled a “crowd control exercise” they had planned for Tuesday between a Hispanic neighborhood and its designated polling place after civil rights groups and lawmakers slammed it as a voter intimidation tactic. (📸: Getty)

Before 1920, it was illegal for women to vote in many places across the US. After a long and arduous fight by suffragettes in both Congress and the streets, the nineteenth amendment became a part of the constitution 🇺🇸📩 (📷: Getty, Shutterstock, Bettmann Archive)
Ariana Grande’s new single “Thank u, Next” is about how she’s moved on and grown stronger after her romantic relationships, and of course it became a meme 💞 (📷: Twitter)

Brent Taylor, the mayor of North Ogden City, was stationed in Afghanistan as part of his fourth deployment when he was killed in an apparent insider attack. The Purple Heart recipient made a difference in the life of Afghan army pilot Abdul Rahman Rahmani, who served alongside Taylor on some missions. In a letter addressed to Taylor's wife and their seven children, Rahmani wrote that in Afghanistan, women and children are often treated unfairly but that Taylor’s compassion and love inspired him to be a “better father, a better husband and a better man." Swipe 👈 to read the full letter 💌 (📷: Utah National Guard/Abdul Rahman Rahmani)

The UK tour comes 23 years after the release of “Wannabe”. There will be one person missing: Posh Spice. "I won't be joining my girls on stage again but being in the Spice Girls was a hugely important part of my life and I wish them so much love and fun as they go back on tour next year,” Victoria Beckham said 🎶🇬🇧 (📷: @spicegirls)

Amazon shoppers, regardless of their Prime member status, will get free standard shipping on orders delivered through the holiday season starting today. The shipments will take five to eight business days to arrive. For Prime members, Amazon is offering free same-day delivery 📦🙌 (📷: Getty)

A college student named Quran is now admitting a viral story she tweeted about getting kicked out of her house for supporting the president, which led to some Trump supporters donating money to her, was all a lie. Quran admitted to BuzzFeed News that she made up the entire event — including the screenshotted texts with her mom. She stated that she doesn't "really support Trump" and that she couldn't "act like I support Trump genuinely." "A lot of Republicans have this idea that everyone thinks Republicans are mostly racist and they’re really desperate to get that stigma off of them," she said. "I just felt like capitalizing on that." Quran has returned all the money that was donated to her. (📷: Twitter)

The driver admitted he was "huffing" chemicals when he drove into the Girl Scout troop, who were cleaning trash from the side of the highway, according to police. Three troop members were killed: 9-year-old Jayna Kelley, 10-year-old Autum Helgeson, and 10-year-old Haylee Hickle. Haylee's mother, 32-year-old Sara Jo Schneider, was also killed. Another 10-year-old girl who was hit by the car is still hospitalized, but in stable condition as of Monday. (📷: AP)

Rihanna’s tweet came after she saw a tweet from a reporter saying that her song “Don’t Stop the Music” was playing at a Trump rally in Chattanooga, Tennessee, ahead of Tuesday’s midterm elections. (📸: Getty Images)

The Pittsburgh rapper died on Sept. 7 at the age of 26, after being found unresponsive at his home. The Los Angeles County Coroner’s Office said in a statement that Miller was found to have died from mixed drug toxicity, and it was determined to be an accident. (📸: Getty Images)

Sam Ballard, 29, died Friday almost a decade after he was infected by rat lungworm, a parasite usually found in rodents, which he picked up after swallowing a slug. He was 19-years-old when he swallowed a slug while hanging out with friends. (📸: Network Ten)

Chris Cornell’s autopsy did not blame drugs as a cause of death, but a toxicology test on his body found traces of barbiturates, caffeine, naloxone, a decongestant, and lorazepam, also known as Ativan. Vicky Cornell and her children say Dr. Robert Koblin prescribed Cornell more than 940 doses of Ativan during the final 20 months of his life. Ativan is typically used to treat seizure disorders like epilepsy, but can also be used after medical procedures to alleviate anxiety. (📷: Getty)

Microwavable noodle and soup products are responsible for 1 in 5 scald burns that send children to the emergency room every year, new research says. Study author Dr. Courtney Allen found that instant noodles are responsible for more than 9,500 burn injuries each year among children ages 4 to 12. The most commonly burned part of the body was the torso, accounting for about 40% of injuries 🍜⚠️ (📷: Getty)

In a purple state, Andrew Gillum ran a progressive campaign that aimed for intersectionality and embraced the ideas of the new left. “The US has only had four black Governors in its entire history, and we can help make #AndrewGillum the next one and Florida’s first!” @badgalriri wrote on Instagram. She also encouraged people to vote yes on Amendment 4 🗳🇺🇸 (📷: AP)
👑🎂😮 (📸: PA Images)

"I love her look and I have always been a fan of her...yes I'm Big but I work with what I got 💕," Alicia Mitchell wrote on Twitter after an old photo of her Aaliyah costume was shared online. "My thing is, you have to be happy with who you are," Mitchell told BuzzFeed News. (📸: YouTube/@fatgirlglamour)
She dropped the new song, titled "thank u, next," 30 minutes before SNL aired Saturday night 🎤🎶 (📸: Reuters)

Three Girl Scouts and an adult woman were killed in a hit-and-run crash Saturday in western Wisconsin. The troop was picking up trash along a county road when a Ford pickup truck left the roadway and struck multiple people, leaving four dead and another Girl Scout in critical condition. The driver, identified as 21-year-old Colton Treu, fled the area but later turned himself in, police said. (📸: AP)

The man who shot dead two women at a yoga studio in Tallahassee, Florida, before killing himself was a far-right extremist, self-proclaimed misogynist, and possible "involuntary celibate," or incel, who railed against women, black people, and immigrants in a series of online videos and songs. Scott Beierle was named by police as the shooter who opened fire inside the Hot Yoga Tallahassee studio, killing two and injuring four other women and a man. Those killed were Dr. Nancy Van Vessem, 61, and FSU student Maura Binkley, 21. YouTube has since suspended Beierle’s account. The suspect was reportedly arrested in 2012 and 2016 for grabbing women’s buttocks without their consent. (📸: Getty)

As dusk fell around the US on Friday night, people lined up at synagogues — with some lines stretching back blocks. People also used #ShowUpForShabbat to show express solidarity with the Jewish community. (📸: Getty Images)

According to @gothamist, the duck first appeared in October and has stayed put since. Park officials initially planned on capturing the bird and bringing it to safety, but it's doing well in the wild so they decided to let it be 🦆 (📸: Getty Images)

Dr. Nancy Van Vessem, 61, who worked at FSU’s College of Medicine, and student Maura Binkley, 21, were killed Friday when a gunman opened fire at a Tallahassee yoga studio Friday, before killing himself. Five other people were also injured. (📸: Facebook/FSU)

A gunman killed one person and injured at least four others Friday when he opened fire at a Tallahassee, Florida, yoga studio before killing himself, officials said. Local media identified the location as the Hot Yoga Tallahassee at the Betton Hills Complex. When officers arrived they found multiple victims with gunshot wounds and transported 5 people to hospitals, where one person died. Four people are in critical condition, and officials are working to identify them and notify their families. Police said they have not yet identified the shooter, who died from what appears to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound. A city spokesman said the shooting appeared to be a part of a domestic dispute. (📸: TallyPD via Facebook)

Trump tweeted a Game of Thrones–related image Friday with text that read “Sanctions are coming.” The president was referring to an announcement that the US will be fully reinstating sanctions against Iran, which comes nearly six months after Trump backed out of the Iran nuclear deal. People on Twitter had a lot of thoughts about the meme, and HBO was not pleased, telling BuzzFeed News: "We were not aware of this messaging and would prefer our trademark not be misappropriated for political purposes.” Even the cast of the hit HBO show was not having it: "Not today," Maisie Williams (aka Arya Stark) tweeted. (📸: @ realdonaldtrump via Twitter)

A school district in Idaho is investigating a Facebook post that showed staff at an elementary school dressed as Mexicans and a "Make America Great Again" wall for Halloween. Superintendent Josh Middleton he was "deeply troubled" by the costumes, which he also called "insensitive" and "inappropriate." The photos were soon deleted from the Middleton School District's Facebook page. But an organization called Idaho DACA Students provided BuzzFeed News with screenshots of the original post, which were sent in by a concerned parent. The organization has since started a petition in response to the costumes demanding the district "provide awareness and consciousness of systemic racism" through training and policy changes. (📸: Idaho DACA Students Facebook)

The image of an emaciated Amal Hussain was shared around the world last week, drawing attention to Yemen's civil war and famine. Amal — whose name means "hope" in Arabic — died in a refugee camp, four miles from a hospital, on Oct. 26, her mother told the Times. (📸: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times)

Trump suggested soldiers could fire on anyone from the caravan of Central American migrants who throws a rock because "there's not much difference" between a stone and a gun. Retired Gen. Mark Hertling said troops would not do that, and called it "an unlawful order." (📸: Getty Images)

Google employees around the globe staged walkouts to protest gender inequality and a company culture that protected executives accused of sexual misconduct. The companywide protest began in Google's Tokyo office, and ballooned to thousands of participants across offices in Singapore, Japan, Israel, Switzerland, Germany, the UK, and Ireland. The largest walkouts occurred in New York, San Francisco, and at the company's Mountain View, California headquarters. The protest represents frustration with Google's treatment of women and minorities, as well as outcry over the recent revelation that the company paid $90 million to Android creator Andy Rubin when he left Google, despite an allegation he coerced an employee to perform oral sex. In Mountain View, female employees spoke about being sexually harassed by coworkers, and silenced by Google's HR when they reported it. Google CEO Sundar Pichai told employees in an email supporting the walkouts that "you have the support you need." (📸: Getty)

Uber will cover online college tuition costs and offer other perks like discounted fuel to its top drivers as part of a new program called Uber Pro that launches Thursday in eight markets. “Drivers earn status by getting points and by giving great service — those unlock status,” Uber said. “We want to recognize commitment from drivers.” Under the Pro program, drivers will be ranked in three tiers — gold, platinum, and diamond. For platinum and diamond drivers who’ve driven more than 3,000 rides with Uber, the ride-hail company will cover the cost of tuition for Arizona State University's online program — for children, spouses, and parents as well. Uber Pro drivers will also receive discounts at gas station and auto repair shops. The program will be tested first in Seattle, Chicago, New Orleans, New Jersey, Orlando, Tampa, Phoenix, and Denver. Drivers in these markets who would have qualified for Uber Pro in the last three months will automatically be added to it. (📸: Uber)
Every year @heidiklum has a wild costume, and this year she trolled everyone at her Halloween party. Her boyfriend, Tom Kaulitz, dressed as Shrek. (📸: AP)

Parker Curry was photographed staring in awe at Michelle Obama's official portrait in March. Her mom told BuzzFeed News that when she asked Parker what she wanted to dress as for Halloween, the toddler's response was immediate. “Flat out. No hesitation. Half of a second later. 'I want to be Michelle Obama,' and I was like Whoa" (📸: Ben Hines / Jessica Curry)

Princess Ayako married commoner Kei Moriya at Meiji Shrine in Tokyo on Monday, thus renouncing her royal status and becoming the latest female royal to leave Japan’s imperial family 🇯🇵💍 👑 Follow @world for more headlines from around the 🌍 (📷: AP)

The bodies of Meenakshi "Minaxi" Moorthy, 30, and Vishnu Viswanath, 29, were recovered roughly 800 feet below Taft Point after a specialized team was able to reach them, officials said. Together, they ran the Instagram account @holidaysandhappilyeverafters, where they posted about their world travels. Exactly how the couple ended up falling remains under investigation. But Viswanath's brother said they had set up a tripod on the ledge to get a selfie. The next day, park visitors saw the camera and alerted officials. (📷: Facebook)

Signs discouraging kids from trick-or-treating have been placed in the yards of homes of registered sex offenders in one county in Georgia ahead of Halloween. Sheriff Gary Long of Butts County said that the signs will “notify the public that it's a house to avoid.” The sheriff said that Georgia law states that registered sex offenders cannot participate in the holiday. Butt told CBS that some sex offenders have emailed him and called the signs embarrassing. "My job is to ensure the safety of the children and the community and that's what I'm going to do." (📸: Butts County Sheriff)

"Good luck trying to cancel me. It's so easy for anyone to be like, 'Logan Paul just ended his career, he’s done.' But the only person who will ever decide whether that’s true is me," Paul told the Hollywood Reporter. (📸: Getty Images / YouTube)

Oprah will join Abrams, who is running to become Georgia’s governor, at two local town halls and knock on doors for her. Other prominent Democrats, including Barack Obama, Elizabeth Warren, and Joe Biden, have also campaigned for Abrams, who will become the US’s first black woman governor if she wins 🍑🗳 (📸: Getty Images)

On Tuesday, the rapper returned to Twitter to clarify the issues he supports, including prison reform and common-sense gun laws. He also shut down recent accusations that he designed the shirts for Candace Owens' Blexit campaign, which seeks to convince black voters to exit the Democratic Party. While Kanye thanked those who support his "ACTUAL beliefs," it is unclear who, if anyone, pushed him to provide the clarification. (📷: AP/Getty)

Three-quarters of Venice was flooded Monday following strong storms that swept through Italy. At high tide, water levels in the city were 5 feet above sea level, forcing tourists and residents to wade through waist-high water. Venice is prone to floods in the autumn and winter months, but the recent flooding, fueled by strong winds, is the worst in at least 10 years. (📷: Getty/Reuters)

Though details are thin, HBO says Naomi Watts will be portraying "a charismatic socialite hiding a dark secret." Per the show's logline, it'll take place "thousands of years before the events of Game of Thrones." 🎬🐉 (📷: Getty/HBO)

The 89-year-old former Winter Hill Gang leader was moved to the Hazelton federal prison in West Virginia from a prison in Florida in the last 24 hours. He was “found unresponsive” at 8:20 a.m. The circumstances around his death remain unclear, but the Boston Globe reported “a fellow inmate with Mafia ties is being investigated for the slaying.” (📷: Getty Images)
Our morning newsletter gives you the news you need to start your day with inspo to help slay your day. Link in bio to sign up 💪

“Happy” was played ahead of Trump’s appearance at the Future Farmers of America rally on Saturday, hours after 11 people were killed in the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting. “There was nothing ‘happy’ about the tragedy inflicted upon our country on Saturday and no permission was granted for your use of this song for this purpose.” Williams’ lawyer wrote to Trump. (📸: Getty Images)

Even if Trump were to sign an executive order to this effect, it would wind up in court, and the Supreme Court has made a clear ruling on the right to citizenship for those born in the United States. While talking about his plans, Trump falsely claimed the US is the only country in the world that grants automatic citizenship to people born on its soil. More than 30 countries across the world grant birthright citizenship. (📸: Getty Images)

The Chinese government has overturned its 25-year-long ban on the use of tiger and rhino body parts in medicine. The new policy states that the parts “can only be used in qualified hospitals by qualified doctors recognized by the State Administration of Traditional Chinese Medicine." Rhino horns have traditionally been "used to treat fever, rheumatism, gout, and other disorders." Tiger bone is used for impotence and flagging libido. (📷: Reuters/Getty)

The US military announced that 5,200 troops would soon join 2,092 National Guard members who were deployed in April along the border, bringing the total number of US troops there to roughly 7,300. That is more than are currently deployed to Iraq and Syria, and about half the US military presence of 15,000 in Afghanistan. The troops would also outnumber the group of migrants moving toward the border by more than two to one. Two-thirds of those migrants are women and children. (📷: Getty/Reuters)

A Lion Air plane carrying 189 people, including one child and two infants, crashed into the ocean after taking off from Jakarta on Monday morning. The flight bound for Pangkal Pinang, an island off Sumatra, lost contact less than 15 minutes after it took off. No survivors have been found. Officials investigating the crash are now focused on retrieving the black box and data transmitted from the cockpit of the aircraft. (📷: Getty Images)

Jordan Fisher will play Mark Cohen, the main narrator who documents his and his friends’ lives in NYC. Vanessa Hudgens will play Maureen Johnson. Tinashe will play the role of Mimi Marquez, the dancer who fights a battle with drugs. Mario will act as Benjamin Coffin III, Mark’s landlord and once-friend, and Valentina will perform as Angel Dumott Schunard, a drag queen who finds out they’re HIV-positive and dies at a young age. The live musical premieres in January 🎬🎭 (📷: Getty Images)

The six-part documentary series will start streaming on November 16, Netflix says, and will set out to prove “the unconditional love one feels for their dog is a beautiful universal truth.” We’re already crying tbh 🐶 😍 😭 (📸: Netflix)

A Justin Bieber look-alike was hired by a group called Yes Theory to trick everyone online into believing he would eat a burrito sideways. As they expected, a photo of their Bieber imposter (a man named Brad Sousa) went viral, leading many to wonder why the pop star seemed to be eating a burrito all wrong. The group said they wanted to show that staging a story can be done “more easily than imagined.” (📷: Yes Theory / YouTube)

A former patient of Dr. Jerry Rabinowitz, a 66-year-old physician, said the doctor was a particular hero to Pittsburgh’s LGBT community at the height of the AIDS epidemic. “He would hold my hand, without gloves, when I was feeling really bad,” the patient wrote on Facebook. He “kept us alive the longest.” (📸: Michael Kerr)
The Eiffel Tower in Paris went dark on Sunday in honor of the 11 victims who were killed by a gunman at a Pittsburgh synagogue. (📷: Getty)

Sydney Allen has a rare condition called syringomyelia that can build up spinal fluid in the spinal cord. When she went in for a check up this week, doctors took an X-ray of her spine. She thought nothing of it till her doctor pulled up her X-ray results in front of her mom. "My mom saw my piercings as soon as the X-ray popped up and the doctor and I started laughing hysterically," Allen said, adding that her mom has warmed up to the piercings because they're hidden 😬 (📷: Sydney Allen)

US immigration officials said 93% of the 401 applicants established that they had a credible fear of torture or persecution in their home country because of their race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group, or political opinion. (📷: Luc Forsyth for BuzzFeed News)

A gunman shouting anti-Semitic statements opened fire inside the Tree of Life synagogue in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, on Saturday morning, leaving a trail of death and destruction. Three different congregations had been meeting for regular Shabbat services. Eleven worshippers didn't make it out alive. Some of the victims included a husband and wife, pair of brothers, a trusted doctor, and a 97-year-old grandmother. A suspect has now been arrested and charged under federal hate crime laws. (📷: Facebook, NPR, Supplied)

In World War I, a "significant minority" of soldiers were having sex while stationed on the front line — but the presence of wartime sex workers who helped rally the troops has been mostly forgotten. They worked in brothels frequented by troops serving on the front line in northern France, but their role has been virtually erased from the history books. (📷: Getty Images/ Social Welfare History Archives/ Bettmann Archive)

Simone Biles shone at the World Artistic Gymnastics Championships, where she recorded the highest scores for three events despite having just been in the hospital with a kidney stone. The reigning Olympic champion secured the highest individual scores on the beam, vault, and floor, and placed second on the uneven bars. Her stunning performance all but ensured that the US team will qualify for the team final with an impressive 12-point lead ahead of the second-place competitor, Japan 🤸🏾‍♀️🏅🇺🇸 (📷: Getty Images)

Authorities have released the names of the 11 people killed at the Tree of Life synagogue in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. They range in age from 54 to 97 and include a husband and wife and a pair of brothers.

Members of the Squirrel Hill community held a candlelight vigil in remembrance of the 11 people who were killed when a gunman opened fire at the Tree of Life Synagogue in the Squirrel Hill neighborhood of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Officials are investigating the shooting, which also injured six other people including four police officers, as a hate crime. The gunman will face federal charges that carry the death penalty, the US Justice Department said. (📸: Getty)

The man suspected of opening fire inside a Pennsylvania synagogue Saturday, killing 11 and injuring at least 6 others, was a neo-Nazi who hated Jews, migrants, and refugees, and pushed a white-supremacist agenda online. During the shooting, Robert Bowers allegedly said he wanted all Jews to die. He was active on Gab, a messaging platform that is a hub for white nationalists and the alt-right. Using the alias OneDingo, he shared and wrote vitriolic posts and memes attacking Jews, as well as Muslims, calling them "filthy" and "evil." Shortly before the massacre, Bowers took to Gab to lash out at HIAS, a Jewish nonprofit that helps refugees, writing that he could not "sit by and watch my people get slaughtered. Screw your optics, I am going in." In a statement, Gab said they disavowed "all acts of terrorism and violence" and has since suspended the account. (📸: web.archive.org)

Eleven people have been killed, and four police officers wounded, after a gunman opened fire in a synagogue in Pennsylvania on Saturday in an attack described by officials as a hate crime. Suspect Robert Bowers is now in custody after the shooting at the Tree of Life synagogue, authorities said. The gunman was armed with an assault rifle and at least three hand guns, officials said. Trump called the shooting an "anti-semitic act," but appeared to place at least some blame on synagogue officials, telling reporters the shooting could have been prevented by an armed security guard. (📸: Getty Images)

Nasro Araye said she and her friends were inspired by seeing Ibtihaj Muhammad, the first Muslim woman to represent the US at the Olympics wearing a hijab. Nike developed a hijab for sports, working with Muhammad and other Muslim women athletes, and released it last year. “Honestly everything is so surreal right now,” Araye told BuzzFeed News. “I did not expect to get this much attention.” (📸: Falza Mohamed and Amina Araye)

Four police officers were also wounded after a gunman opened fire at the Tree of Life synagogue during a Shabbat service on Saturday morning. A suspect is in custody and receiving medical attention, authorities said. “The scene is very bad inside,” the Pittsburgh’s public safety director said. “It’s a very horrific crime scene, it’s one of the worst that I’ve seen.” (📸: Alexandra Wimley and Andrew Stein/@pittsburghpg via AP)

“He says ‘I’m going to protect your preexisting conditions’ while his Justice Department is in court right now trying to strike down those protections,” Obama said while rallying for candidates in the Midwest. The former president slammed Republicans for spending eight years trying to end the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, and then in “the final weeks before an election pretending you’re Florence Nightingale.” (📸: Getty Images)

Gregory Bush, 51, was charged with shooting and killing two black people at a Kroger supermarket outside Louisville, Kentucky Wednesday in what is being investigated as a possible hate crime. The victims have been identified as Maurice Stallard, 69, and Vickie Jones, 67, who are both black and were shopping at the store at the time. Prior to the shooting, security footage showed Bush had tried to gain access to the nearby First Baptist Church, a predominately black church. After the killings, Bush reportedly told a white man, “Don't shoot me. I won't shoot you. Whites don’t shoot whites.” (📸: Getty, AP)

Olympic gold medalist Simone Biles tweeted a photo Friday from the hospital insisting that not even a kidney stone will stop her from competing at the 2018 World Gymnastics Championships in Qatar. "This kidney stone can wait...doing it for my team!" Biles tweeted. The pledge to compete in the event, which kicks into high gear this weekend, left her fans shook yet again: "Wonder Woman's got NOTHING on Simone," one tweeted. (📸: @ Simone_Biles via Twitter)

Authorities arrested 56-year-old Cesar Altieri Sayoc in Florida and charged him with five federal crimes in connection with the series of pipe bomb packages addressed to prominent Democrats and critics of President Trump. The FBI uncovered Sayoc's latent fingerprint from one of the envelopes containing a pipe bomb. A white van covered in pro-Trump stickers, including one that read "CNN Sucks," was also seized in Florida. Sayoc is a Trump supporter who frequently attended pro-Trump rallies and events, according to his social media posts. (📸: Facebook)

NBC has canceled Megyn Kelly’s morning show days after her on-air defense of blackface created a crisis at the network. Kelly has been on shaky ground at NBC for months over the show’s failure to be a ratings star as well as a raft of on-air stumbles. (📷: AP)

The ’90s teen classic movie is coming back. The project is still in its early stages, but Paramount Pictures has announced it will be helmed with writers from “Girls Trip” (Tracy Oliver) and “GLOW” (Marquita Robinson). (📷: Paramount Pictures)

A week after making his cabinet half women, Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has appointed Sahle-Work Zewde has the country’s first female president. Although the position is considered a largely ceremonial one, Sahle-Work’s appointment carries significant symbolic weight and makes her the only female head of state in Africa. Follow @world for more headlines from around the 🌍 (📷: Reuters, Getty

At least one person is dead and more than 50,000 people are without power after Typhoon Yutu ravaged the Northern Mariana Islands. The Category 5 storm passed over the island of Tinian on Thursday with sustained winds of 178 mph, the most intense cyclone to ever pass over the islands, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The tin roofs of many residential homes were ripped off, hundreds of power lines were toppled, and beautiful white sand beaches appear to have been wiped out. (📷: Reuters, AP, Facebook)

After two years of saying she's disappointed by the Trump administration's policies, Caitlyn Jenner has announced that she is no longer supporting the president. "Sadly, I was wrong," Jenner wrote in the Washington Post. “It’s clear these policies have come directly from Trump, and they have been sanctioned, passively or actively, by the Republicans by whose continued support he governs. My hope in him — in them — was misplaced, and I cannot support anyone who is working against our community," she wrote. "I do not support Trump. I must learn from my mistakes and move forward." 🏳️‍🌈⚤ (📷: Getty Images)

24-year-old Uzma Nawaz has become one of Pakistan’s first female car mechanics. Nawaz graduated with a degree in mechanical engineering and now works at an auto repairs garage. “I took it up as a challenge against all odds and the meagre financial resources of my family,” Nawaz said 🧕🛠🚗 Follow @world for more stories from around the 🌍

20-year-old Megan Rixson said she ended up with swelling, redness, eyes that wouldn’t stop watering, and even lost her sight for two hours after she got her lashes done at a local salon. Eyelash extensions are hugely popular right now, but there’s a lack of regulation for the procedure, which means it’s easy to go somewhere that doesn’t do it safely. One optometrist said there are so many things that can go wrong — inflammation, an allergic reaction, potential ulcers and vision loss — that his first advice is to simply not do it and get some good mascara instead. (📷: Rixson)

Megyn Kelly will not be live on her NBC show for the rest of the week, after she defended blackface on air Tuesday and amid reported fighting at NBC News over her future. The show will instead air reruns. (📷: Getty Images)

Since the release of her album "Sweetener," Ariana Grande has had a tough couple of months, mourning the death of her ex-boyfriend, Mac Miller, and breaking off her engagement to Pete Davidson. So fans were understandably surprised when she began tweeting hints that a new album was already on the way, mere months after her last one. Grande had already teased new music prior to her split from Davidson, and in a series of tweets thanked fans for supporting her. (📸: Getty)

After a pipe bomb was delivered to CNN's New York headquarters forcing an evacuation while anchors were live on air, CNN President Jeff Zucker called out President Trump for antagonizing words about the media. “There is a total and complete lack of understanding at the White House about the seriousness of their continued attacks on the media," Zucker said. "The President, and especially the White House Press Secretary, should understand their words matter." (📸: Getty)

The suspect is wanted in the UK in connection to a theft at a local restaurant.
