And yes, police are well-aware of who the now-viral photo looks like. “We have investigated this matter thoroughly and have confirmed that David Schwimmer was in America on this date,” police said. Schwimmer joked about the whole thing by tweeting a video of himself pretending to be the thief. (📸: Blackpool Police and David Schwimmer)

“We see vividly, painfully how technology can harm, rather than help,” the Apple CEO said at a conference in Brussels, adding that platforms can “magnify our worst human tendencies … deepen divisions, incite violence, and even undermine our shared sense or what is true or false.” (📸: Getty Images)

Authorities intercepted potential explosive devices addressed to Clinton's New York home and to Obama's Washington DC residence. They were identified during routine mail screening procedures, the Secret Service said. (📸: AP)

East Island, which is located about 550 miles northwest of Honolulu, appears to have all but disappeared after being ravaged by Hurricane Walaka. Scientists at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration made the discovery when they noticed satellite images of the area where the island once rose above the ocean no longer showed very much land. Biologists likely won't return to the remote area until next year, when they will do an assessment of the damage. (📷: NOAA)

Aaron Gouveia says his 5-year-old son, Sam, loves to get his nails done by his grandma, but came home in tears because he was bullied for his polish. Gouveia was heartsick over his son's pain and decided to share the story to speak out against toxic masculinity. “While we've empowered girls to do and be anything, the same doesn't hold true for boys," Gouveia said. He wants all parents to "allow our boys to experience their full range of emotions without fear or shame.” 👏 (📷: Aaron Gouveia)

In summing up her public life, Sandra Day O'Connor expressed gratitude. "As a young cowgirl from the Arizona desert, I never could have imagined that one day I would become the first woman justice on the U.S. Supreme Court," she continued. "I hope that I have inspired young people about civic engagement and helped pave the pathway for women who may have faced obstacles pursuing their careers." (📷: Getty/@hauserportraits)

Nina Koupriianova, who married Spencer in August 2010 and has two young children with him, alleges that Spencer physically abused her, including instances where she was “being hit, being grabbed, being dragged around by her hair, being held down in a manner causing bruising, and being prevented from calling for help.” “I dispute many of her assertions,” Spencer said in court filings, adding that he “denies each, every, and all allegations.” (📷: Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images)

The Indianapolis Zoo said keepers had never noticed any aggression between the two lions before and will conduct a review to understand what led to the altercation. A necropsy confirmed that the lion died of suffocation from injuries to the neck. The 12-year-old lioness was uninjured. (📸: Indianapolis Zoo)

“But what is racist?” Kelly asked her all-white panel. “Back when I was a kid that was ok, as long as you were dressing up as, like, a character.” Kelly also defended a Diana Ross costume from “The Real Housewives of New York” star Luann de Lesseps that drew backlash last year. (📸: NBC)

On Sunday, more than 7,200 migrants pushed slowly into Mexico from Guatemala as they made their way toward the US in hopes of seeking asylum from gang violence and extreme poverty. The caravan of mostly Honduran migrants was met at Mexico’s southern border by riot police who deployed tear gas in response to clashes between the two groups. (📷: Reuters)

A white woman was caught on camera confronting a Spanish-speaking family while they were dining at a restaurant. The woman, whose identity was not known, screamed obscenities at the Spanish speaking woman who was dining with her seven-year-old child and other members of her family and demanded they show her their passports. “Go back to your fucking country,” the woman yelled. “You do not fucking come over here and freeload on America.” In a Facebook post, the restaurant condemned the actions of the harassing woman, saying she will not be welcome back at the establishment. "Thank you — and we mean this with all the aforementioned respect that you rightfully deserve — for never returning to Andy’s," the restaurant said on Facebook. "You are not welcome." (📷: Telemundo 44, Facebook)

Protesters gathered in New York City in response to an unreleased Trump administration memo that proposes a strict definition of gender based on a person’s genitalia at birth. The Trump administration is reportedly considering re-defining gender as a “biological, immutable condition determined by genitalia at birth.” #WontBeErased ✊ ⚤ Follow @buzzfeedlgbt for more 🏳️‍🌈 news. (📷: Getty Images)
The episode, co-written by Malorie Blackman, centered around Rosa Parks and received significant viewer and critical acclaim for its unflinching portrayal of racism and discrimination. (📷 : BBC)

A new caravan of more than 7,200 migrants have started walking through the southern Mexican state of Chiapas, defying threats from Trump to stop them and attempts by the government of Mexico to process people into the country individually | 📷: Reuters

At least 59 people were killed and 90 others injured when a train traveling at high speed plowed into a crowd. The victims had been watching a celebration for Hindu festival Dusshera and had moved onto some railway tracks during the event. Follow @world for more headlines from around the 🌏

“You’re a traitor to this country!” a witness said one woman yelled at the Senate majority leader and his wife, Secretary of Transportation Elaine Chao, before she went outside and flipped off the couple through the window. A second man yelled at the Senator about social security and health care, and is seen on video asking “Why don’t you get out of here? Why don’t you leave the entire country?” According to the witness, that man later flung McConnell’s to-go box out onto the sidewalk. (📷: TMZ)

Police say they’re unaware of any life-threatening injuries from the event. Students said the floor collapsed just before the beat dropped, when people at the party were jumping up and down. The incident was captured on multiple social media videos, and took place at an apartment hours after Clemson University’s football team won their homecoming game 41-7. (📷: AP)

The 46-year-old actor said she has “had symptoms for years but was never taken seriously … I am in the thick of it but hope to give some hope to others.” MS is an incurable condition affecting the brain or spinal cord, causing vision, balance, and muscle problems. “I am disabled. I fall sometimes. I drop things. My memory is foggy. And my left side is asking for directions from a broken GPS,” Blair wrote and thanked her loved ones and coworkers for their support. (📷: @selmablair)

Detroit police said that 36 fetuses were discovered in boxes, and 27 were found in the freezer at the Perry Funeral Home, which is now under investigation. This is the second such discovery in Detroit recently after the bodies of 11 infants, including 10 fetuses, were found in another funeral home. (📸: AP)

Coral Springs, Florida police claim video of officers pinning down and hitting a black 14-year-old girl was justified because she was "acting aggressive." Police said officers were called to a mall after patrons reported "unruly teens," including one mother who told an officer "her 5-year-old was shoved to the ground by one of the teens." The teens were then barred from the mall and given a trespass warning, but some returned, police said, including the 14-year-old girl. Officers said she began fighting officers and resisting arrest, and they had no choice but to pin her down. The girl's mother says she feels she "can't trust" police anymore, and the family has hired an attorney. (📸: @ victoria_babyyy)

John Waddell, 62, was found dehydrated and with broken bones three days after falling down a 100-foot mining shaft in Arizona. While down there, he had to kill three rattlesnakes to avoid being bitten. Waddell is an experienced miner, and had gone to his friend's property to prospect for stones and metals, but the rappelling device he used to lower himself down into the mine failed and he became stuck. A Vietnam-era veteran, Waddell used military survival skills to manage for three days until his friend drove out to the mine and heard him yelling. Waddell is undergoing surgery for injuries to his leg, but is in high spirits, and as his friend said, is “a tough SOB." (📸: Maricopa County Sheriff’s Office)

Leonne Zeegers, a former athlete and nurse, received a passport with a gender designation of X instead of M for “mannetje” (male) or V for “vrouw” (female). Zeegers won a landmark lawsuit in May when judges ruled that preventing someone from registering as gender-neutral was “a violation of private life, self-determination and personal autonomy.” The Netherlands now joins Argentina, Australia, Canada, Denmark, India, Malta, Nepal, New Zealand, and Pakistan as countries that offer a gender-neutral option on passports. (📷: EPA/Getty) Follow @world and @buzzfeedlgbt for more!

Charlie Hinderliter is encouraging everyone to get vaccinated after he ended up in a coma after he got the flu in January. He skipped his vaccine in the fall because he thought he didn’t need one. And when he got the flu in January, he expected to recover quickly — instead, two weeks later, he was in a coma with pneumonia, septic shock, and total organ failure. Doctors told his family to make funeral arrangements. Hinderliter recovered after spending 58 days in the ICU, but full recovery will still take him about six more months. The best way to protect yourself and others is to get vaccinated: the CDC recommends everyone 6 months and older do so by the end of October. (📷: Hinderliter)

Over 50 former patients said in a class-action lawsuit that among other things, George Tyndall sexually assaulted patients, demanded unnecessary pelvic exams, and made lewd comments while they were undressed. Tyndall was the only full-time gynecologist at the University of Southern California for decades, even though the college acknowledged it had received complaints about his behavior dating back to the 1990s. Over 500 people total have come forward to accuse Tyndall of inappropriate behavior. (📷: Getty)

This is the largest lottery in jackpot history. Friday’s winning numbers were: 65 53 23 15 70. Mega Ball: 7. The odds of winning the Mega Millions grand prize are 1 in 302,575,350 — in comparison, your odds of being struck by lightning within your lifetime are 1 in 14,600. So you totally have a shot! 🤷‍♂️💰 (📷: Getty)

A school district in Nebraska has fired a chef who added kangaroo meat to chili served to students. Parents of children in the Potter-Dix school district were informed in a letter that the district's head cook, Kevin Frei, mixed the meat, which the district purchased from its food distributor, with beef. The letter from school superintendent Mike Williams stated that Frei did so because kangaroo is a "very lean meat" that he thought could add "nutritional value" to the chili. Williams said that kangaroo meat is not unhealthy or dangerous, and is perfectly legal to consume, but he disagreed with the decision it serve it. One parent said she wasn't even necessarily mad that it was served, but upset that it wasn't disclosed beforehand. (📸: Getty)

Saudi Arabia has finally acknowledged that Washington Post journalist Jamal Khashoggi was killed, two weeks after he disappeared inside the country's consulate in Turkey. Khashoggi, who lived in the US, entered the consulate on Oct. 2 to obtain documents needed for his upcoming marriage while his fiancee waited outside, but he never returned. Turkish media has reported that Khashoggi was tortured, killed and dismembered on orders from Saudi Arabia's crown prince, while Saudia Arabia claims Khashoggi was killed after a fight broke out in the consulate. The Saudi public prosecutor says 18 Saudi nationals have been arrested in relation to Khashoggi's death. (📸: AP)

Burger King has released a Scary Black Cherry slushie, and people are reporting that the slushie turned their poop various shades ranging from bright blue to black. Most people seem to be enjoying, and it isn't the first time a Burger King menu item has turned poop funny colors: a few years ago, the fast food chain released a Whopper with a black bun that turned people's poop green. The suspected culprit in that case was a bunch of food dye, which is likely the case for the Scary Black Cherry slushie, and is harmless. Happy Halloween! (📸: Burger King)

“She doesn’t agree with the NFL’s stance,” a source told Us Weekly. Kaepernick, who played for the San Francisco 49ers until March 2017, says he has been iced out of the league after launching a wave of player protests against police violence. (📸: Getty Images)

Ainee Fatima, a high school English teacher in Chicago, said she was grading papers and became frustrated. "The answers they were writing were just incredibly wrong. So I was like, let's print out some memes." Her students loved it. (📸: Ainee Fatima)

The retired Lakers star was removed from the jury of the Animation Is Film Festival after a 2003 rape allegation against him resurfaced online. The move reportedly came after a petition was posted last week on Change.org urging the festival organizers to remove Bryant. Bryant responded to the festival’s decision in a statement saying he was “disappointed,” but motivated to build a studio "that focuses on diversity and inclusion in storytelling." In 2003, Bryant was accused of sexually assaulting a Colorado hotel employee. The charges were dropped once his accuser refused to testify, and Bryant made a public apology and settled with the woman in a civil lawsuit in 2005. (📸: Getty)

Rachel Peterson filed a complaint with the ACLU against a Meijer pharmacy in Michigan, claiming a pharmacist refused to fill a prescription she needed to help complete a miscarriage. He allegedly cited his personal religious beliefs — and also refused to transfer the prescription elsewhere. The incident happened in July, after Peterson was told her ultrasound did not have heartbeat and was given a prescription by her doctor for Cytotec, which helps complete a miscarriage. Peterson was eventually able to get the medication from another pharmacy, but decided to file a complaint about the incident. (📸: Rachel Peterson, Google Maps)

A condo building on Manhattan's Upper West Side removed the gold-plated "Trump Place" from its facade, and will be renamed the building's address, 200 Riverside Boulevard. In 2016, residents of the building petitioned to have then-candidate Donald Trump's last name permanently removed, even though the building is still being managed by Trump International Realty. Residents from this location and other Trump Place condos said they were "embarrassed" to be associated with Trump. It's the second Trump-associated building in New York City to physically remove the name since he's become president. (📸: Peterhaskell880 via Twitter)

Of those 92 people, 21 have been hospitalized, although no one has died from the bacteria, the CDC says. Salmonella generally causes vomiting, diarrhea, fever, and stomach cramps about 12 to 72 hours after it is ingested. No specific raw chicken products or retailers have been identified in the outbreak, and the federal agency is also not recalling or asking retailers to stop selling raw chicken products. (📸: Getty Images)

The indictment against Steve Penny says he ordered the removal of documents related to the activities of Nassar, the former USA Gymnastics doctor who was convicted on multiple accounts of sexual assault and child pornography. (📸: Reuters)

"After seven seasons, it’s time to be released from prison,” the show’s creator told BuzzFeed News. Since its premiere in 2013, the show — based on Piper Kerman's memoir, “Orange Is the New Black: My Year in a Women's Prison” — has racked up numerous Emmy nominations, winning a total of four so far. (📷: Netflix)

The total fertility rate in the US is declining — but it’s dropping faster in urban than rural areas. While rural counties saw a decrease of 12% in the total fertility rate, metropolitan counties had a 16–18% drop over the same 10-year period. Meanwhile, the average age when women give birth to their first child is increasing — which means women are having fewer children and waiting longer to start a family. (📷: Getty Images)

Puppeteer Caroll Spinney, who will retire this week, voiced Sesame Street characters Big Bird and Oscar the Grouch for nearly 50 years. “Big Bird brought me so many places, opened my mind and nurtured my soul,” he said. (📸: Sesame Workshop / Robin Marchant

Acute flaccid myelitis typically affects children, causing weakness in the arms and legs, and can even cause trouble breathing. Other symptoms can include a weak or stiff neck and a drooping of the face and eyelids. More than 90% of the people with the condition are children ages 18 or younger, and the average age is 4 years old. Some recover quickly, while others “continue to have paralysis and require ongoing care,” a CDC official said. Given the rise in 2018, there seems to be a pattern with a spike in cases occurring every two years in August and September, but scientists remain unsure of the cause. (📸: Getty Images)

Although weed is legal, it's not without rules. Not all types of cannabis goodies are legal to sell and it was up to each province and territory to decide exactly where weed can be bought, where it can be consumed, and how much can be carried. And despite Canada legalizing it, you're still not going to want to have it on you at the border 🍃💨🇨🇦 (📷: THE CANADIAN PRESS)

Five South Korean climbers — including a world record holder — and their four Nepalese guides have died after a violent snowstorm destroyed their camp on the nearly 24,000-feet Mount Gurja in the Himalaya Mountains in Nepal. Follow @world for more headlines from around the 🌏 (📷: Reuters, Getty, AP)

Mary Bono is stepping down as interim president of USA Gymnastics over a tweet speaking out against Nike and its support of former NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick. “Playing in a charity golf tournament raising money for our nation's Special Forces operators and their families," she wrote. "Unfortunately had these shoes in my bag. Luckily I had a marker in my bag too..." (📷: CQ-Roll Call,Inc./ Twitter)

Authorities in Wisconsin are hunting for 13-year-old Jayme Closs who went missing after her parents were found shot dead in their home. "We're six or eight hours into this," Barron County Sheriff Chris Fitzgerald told reporters Monday, "so we don't know how far she could have gone or if someone took her. We don't know the answer to that. We just know we have a violent crime scene and we're missing a 13-year-old girl." (📷: Facebook)

Toronto police are looking for 37-year-old David Weaver in connection with an assault that occurred Friday — before the shark swimming — outside the Medieval Times in downtown. Police said Weaver fled the scene after allegedly assaulting a man, who was hospitalized with serious injuries sustained in the attack. After fleeing the scene, it seems that Weaver went to the aquarium, about 3 miles away. Because of his shark swimming, Weaver is now also wanted for interfering with property, police said. (📷: thecityissleeping/Toronto police)

The United Arab Emirates, a tiny desert monarchy, hired US ex-special ops soldiers to carry out targeted killings in war-torn Yemen, a BuzzFeed News investigation has revealed. Their months-long mission, according to two participants, was to assassinate prominent clerics and Islamist political figures. Their first attack targeted a local leader of Al-Islah, an Islamist political party. The UAE considers Al-Islah an arm of a terrorist organization — but many experts say it’s not a paramilitary group but a legitimate political party. Abraham Golan, who founded the company the UAE hired, said his team is no murder squad; its targets were legitimate partly because they were deemed terrorists by the the UAE, a US ally. But one of his top lieutenants said he couldn’t rule out that a target might just be someone the UAE crown prince “didn’t like.” (📸: Courtesy Abraham Golan)

Epidemiologists at the Florida Department of Health announced Monday that an unidentified child tested positive for influenza B and died between Sept. 30 and Oct. 6. The child had not been vaccinated and was otherwise healthy, with no known underlying medical conditions. Last winter, an estimated 80,000 people died from flu and its complications, which was the highest number reported by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in 40 years. (📸: Getty Images)

As soon as “The Bachelor Vietnam” contestants Minh Thu and Truc Nhu were separated after Nhu’s elimination from the show, they realized their feelings for each other. Both women said they had never had a same-sex relationship prior to this one, and that the experience of coming out on a TV show was tricky. “When my family asked for an explanation, the response I prepared was, ‘What do you want for me? To have a husband and a child? Or to find my own happiness?’” Thu told BuzzFeed News 🌹 💕 🌈 (📸: YouTube/Truc Nhu/Minh Thu / Via The Bachelor Vietnam)

Never one to let an opportunity to shame the US for its past go by, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, the former president of Iran and current troll extraordinaire, took to his verified Twitter account on Monday to mark the anniversary of the founding of the Black Panther Party. (📷: Getty Images/Mahmoud Ahmadinejad)

Sears’ bankruptcy filing comes more than a decade after the company acquired Kmart for $11 billion, merging two retailers that had struggled to keep up with changing consumer habits as Walmart and Target swept up market share. The country’s first “everything store” has lost 96% of its market value since it went public in 2003. As part of the Chapter 11 bankruptcy restructuring, Sears CEO Eddie Lampert will step down from his position, effective immediately 💰📉 (📷: Getty Images)

Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni said he “held fruitful discussions with the duo on how to promote Uganda's tourism and the arts.” Kanye and his family are visiting Africa for two weeks so he could complete “Yandhi,” a studio album he says will incorporate “sounds that you’ve never heard before.” 👟🇺🇬 (📷: Reuters)

Bad news for beer fans — climate change is expected to hurt barley crops, likely doubling the price of beer in the coming decades, a study says. By the end of this century, it predicts, heat waves and droughts that damage barley will happen once every three years or so, leading to a roughly 16% drop in beer consumption compared to today. (📸: Getty Images)

The email, according to newswire Australian Associated Press, was headlined “meeting” and featured the cat photo, along with some Latin text and an RSVP button. The US embassy in Australia apologized for the email, saying it was a training error made by new staff testing out an email newsletter platform. (📸: Supplied/PR Image)

The baby is due in spring 2019, Kensington Palace announced. Harry and Meghan were said to have shared the news with family members on Friday during Princess Eugenie’s wedding. The child will be seventh in line for the throne, after Harry’s father, Prince Charles; his brother, Prince William; William’s three children, and Harry himself 👑👶🇬🇧 (📸: Getty Images)

James M. Emswiller fell from a balcony while taking a smoke break on the set of “You Are My Friend,” authorities told BuzzFeed News. Police said the 61-year-old’s death may have been precipitated by a medical emergency that caused him to fall. Emswiller was an Emmy-winning sound mixer. “This is a devastating tragedy, and the studio is investigating the matter,” a spokesperson for the studio said. (📷: LinkedIn/Sony Pictures)

From the devastating aftermath of Hurricane Michael to the swearing-in of Justice Brett Kavanaugh, these are the most powerful photos of the week. Follow @buzzfeedphoto for more 📸(📷: Reuters/Getty/AP)

While much of the national conversation around consent has had to with sex, third-grade teacher Liz Kleinrock's lesson is about everyday actions. “Whenever I get frustrated about the state of our country, it inspires me to proactively teach my kids to DO BETTER,” Kleinrock said. She hopes that teaching her students about consent now will ensure they're ready to talk about sexual consent when they're older 👩‍🏫👏 (📷: @teachandtransform)

Steve Bannon was photographed with Michael Brooks, a moderator of a far-right Facebook group who suggested using a swastika in the group's banner and posted about creating a white paramilitary force. Trump’s former White House chief strategist is now working to build a coalition of nationalist parties in Europe and reaching out to several leaders accused of human rights violations and xenophobic rhetoric. (📷: Hope Not Hate)

The program comes after it was reported in 2016 that young girls from low income families were having to use shoe insoles because they couldn’t afford to buy menstrual products. Follow @world for more stories from around the globe 🌎👏 (📷: Seoul Metropolitan Government)

The tent city was meant to be a temporary solution for teens who cross the southern border, because the Trump administration's policy of separating immigrant families at the border meant there weren't enough beds in the shelter system. But four months after opening, the tent city holds roughly 1,500 teens — nearly five times its initial population — and administrative issues are keeping some children there for several months. (📷: HHS)

23-year-old Fiona Simpson was driving with her four-month-old baby and her grandmother when they got caught in a supercell thunderstorm and hail smashed in her car windows. Simpson said she covered the baby with her body while hail pelted them. Despite her severe bruising, she's set to recover and the baby was reported to only have a few small bumps. (📷: Simpson)

In the wake of Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation to the Supreme Court, Chuck Wendig wrote a series of expletive-laced tweets that included one saying Republican senators like Mitch McConnell can "eat a boot covered in shit." Wendig has pointed out that his firing will likely be considered a win for the Comicsgate movement, which harasses writers who seek to make comics more inclusive. Wendig says he was first targeted by the Comicsgate crowd after his "Star Wars: Aftermath" book introduced LGBT characters to the series. (📷: Wendig/Marvel Comics)

Trump said there will be “severe punishment” for those involved in the disappearance of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, but avoided saying whether he would halt military aid to Saudi Arabia if it proved to be implicated. Excerpts of Trump’s interview with "60 Minutes" come as investigators examine allegations that Khashoggi was killed by his own government, and days after he came out against suspending arms sales to its regime. Khashoggi, 59, who writes for the Washington Post, was last seen Oct. 2 entering the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul. Turkish intelligence accused Saudi Arabia of ordering Khashoggi’s murder inside the consulate, but the Saudi authorities dismissed the claims as “lies and baseless accusations." Asked whether Saudi Arabia was involved, Trump said, “Well, nobody knows yet, but we’ll probably be able to find out.” (📸: Getty)

Far-right men’s organization “Proud Boys” violently beat several apparent protesters Friday following a Republican event in Manhattan. About 30 members of the group, which is characterized by the Southern Poverty Law Center as a hate group and extremist group, participated. Despite New York Police Department officers being present, none of the Proud Boys were arrested. However, three protesters were arrested for attacking an event attendee. Police have not yet explained why there were no arrests made in the assault on the three protesters. The NYPD later released a statement saying that it was reviewing additional video and evidence to determine if additional crimes were committed. (📸: Shay Horse)

The right pace to perform CPR compressions matches the tempo of any song that’s 100-120 beats per minute, like “Stayin’ Alive” by the Bee Gees or “Work It” by Missy Elliott. Fortunately, New York-Presbyterian Hospital made a Spotify playlist full of songs with the right tempo for timing compressions. Bonus, it’s full of bangers 🙌 (📸: Getty Images)

Maliha Fairooz and her friends cosplayed as the Avengers at New York Comic Con last weekend and won the event’s Marvel costume category. Fairooz tweeted a photo of all her friends together and people were inspired by their outfits. “It just showed the world is so ready to see something different, people want their perspectives challenged,” Fairooz told BuzzFeed News 💪 (📸: Pharoo Photography)

Although overall vaccination coverage among children in the US remained relatively stable in 2017, a growing percentage of toddlers have received no vaccines at all, according to a new report from the CDC. According to immunization guidelines, children should get vaccinated against 14 potentially serious diseases before their second birthday — but a number of very young children in the US have not been vaccinated against any of these diseases. Vaccination coverage was especially low in rural areas, and the children who were least likely to be vaccinated were those who are uninsured or on Medicaid. (📸: Getty)

Authorities in Savannah, Georgia, have their eyes out for whoever put a pair of googly eyes on a statue of Revolutionary War commander Nathanael Greene. “It may look funny but harming our historic monuments and public property is no laughing matter," the city wrote. "In fact, it's a crime." While the googly eyes didn't do any damage, the city says whoever did it was trespassing and officials urged anyone with information to contact local police. Of course, people have been poking fun at the incident: "I always wanted to visit Savannah, but now that I see how unsafe it is, no thanks," one commenter joked, but the city says people need to know "they can't go around doing whatever they want to our statues." (📸: City of Savannah)

The full link is facebook.com/help/securitynotice. 30 million accounts have had their emails, phone numbers, and other personal information exposed after the recent data breach — valuable information for scammers and spammers.

Todd and Nicole Cameron met on Halloween nearly five years ago and both love crafting incredible costumes. So for their maternity shoot, they recreating the chestbursting scene from the classic 1979 science fiction horror film “Alien.” The photos have gone viral and the couple has created the @burstonoutcameron account for their “baby” if you’d like to follow along with their adventures in parenthood. (📷: Li Carter)

We’re going back to Wakanda, according to the Hollywood Reporter. The 32-year-old director is expected to begin working on the script next year and production is planned to start at the end of 2019 or 2020. “Black Panther” smashed box office records and grossed $1.3 billion globally after it came out in February 💥 (📷: Getty)

Eugenie is the Queen’s granddaughter and the cousin of Princes William and Harry. She had surgery at age 12 to correct scoliosis, and according to the palace, she chose not to wear a veil and worked with her dress designers to create a low back that wouldn’t cover her scar. “It’s a lovely way to honor the people who looked after me and a way of standing up for young people who also go through this,” she said. “I think you can change the way beauty is.” (📷: Getty Images)

Five people died in Virginia and a second person died in Georgia after Hurricane Michael swept through the state on Thursday, officials said, bringing the total death toll for the storm to 12 people. Four of the deaths in Virginia were due to drowning, while a firefighter was killed in a motor vehicle accident. Michael is now a post-tropical cyclone and is over the Atlantic Ocean. (📷: Getty Images)

McKayla Thomas and Bella Schmidt recently celebrated a year and a half together. To commemorate their love Thomas shared some pictures from A Pride event last May. That’s when they noticed another couple photobombing them. “We were just taking pictures, we didn’t even notice that the background was even there until I was editing a few days later,” Thomas told BuzzFeed News 👭👬Follow @buzzfeedlgbt for more 🏳️‍🌈 news. (📸: Supplied)
Kid Rock went to the White House to mark the signing of the Orrin G. Hatch-Bob Goodlatte Music Modernization Act and people online had lots of jokes about his visit 😂 (📷: Reuters/Twitter)

Billy McFarland, the founder of the notorious Fyre Festival, which ended in disaster in 2017, was sentenced to six years in prison on by a federal judge. In March, McFarland pleaded guilty to two counts of wire fraud for defrauding investors and a ticket vendor in connection with the April 2017 event. The music festival had been promoted by social media stars and celebrities like Ja Rule as a luxurious, A-list experience, but it quickly imploded into a calamity as duped guests arrived in the Bahamas to discover disaster-style tents and cheap sandwiches. (📷: AP/ Twitter)

Being interred at the National Cathedral is a rare honor for a private citizen. Shepard, who was gay, was brutally beaten, tied to a fence, and left to die by two men in Laramie, Wyoming in 1998 when he was a college freshman. His death horrified the nation and helped expand federal hate crime legislation, but for years, his family was unable to find a final resting place for their son because they feared any grave might be desecrated. (📷: AP/Matthew Shepard Foundation)

Veronika Didusenko (@veronika_didusenko) was disqualified and stripped of her title after organizers found out that she was a divorced mother. They said she violated the contest’s rules of not being married and not having children. Didusenko told the BBC that the rules are outdated and need to change. For more news from around the 🌍, follow @world. (📸: @veronika_didusenko, @ilyaratman)

Hurricane Michael made landfall on the Florida Panhandle on Wednesday as an extremely dangerous Category 4 storm, with maximum sustained winds reaching 155 mph. Authorities say a Florida man was killed by a falling tree that crashed into his home, while an 11-year-old girl was killed in southwest Georgia. (📸: AP/Getty Images)

Three children in Pittsburgh and another nine in Illinois are suspected to have a mysterious condition called acute flaccid myelitis, which causes a polio-like paralysis. Earlier this week, health officials reported that six other children in Minnesota had been diagnosed with the condition, bringing the total to 18 possible cases in recent weeks. Acute flaccid myelitis can cause symptoms like muscle weakness in the arms or legs, a weak or stiff neck, drooping of the face and eyelids, slurred speech, and in the most severe cases, difficulty breathing. The cause is unclear, but it’s thought to occur after a viral illness, such as a cold or other respiratory infection. (📸: Katy Payne via Facebook)

Hurricane Michael made landfall on the Florida Panhandle as a Category 4 storm Wednesday, with maximum sustained winds reaching 155 mph. One death has been confirmed so far after a Florida man was killed by a falling tree that crashed into his home. Michael is the most intense hurricane to make landfall on the Florida Panhandle, and the strongest to strike the US in the month of October. Michael is now barreling into Georgia as a Category 2 storm. (📸: Getty, AP)

Nauman Hussain was operating Prestige Limousine while his father was out of the country, police said. Hussain had been issued written violations by state police and the Department of Transportation (DoT), and that the driver he hired should not have been operating the type of vehicle that was involved in the crash. Hussain allegedly knew about the violations, and that the 2001 Ford Excursion that was converted to a limo was placed out of service by the DoT in September and should not have been on the road. (📸: Getty)

Joe Giudice is the husband of “Real Housewives of New Jersey” star Teresa Giudice. He has been in federal prison since March 2016 serving a sentence for fraud and will be taken straight from prison to the airport to be flown back to Italy once his sentence is completed. The Giudices both pleaded guilty to four counts of fraud in 2014, and Teresa Guidice completed her 11-month sentence in 2015. (📷: Paul Zimmerman)

The storm made landfall at near-Category 5 strength with maximum sustained winds of 155 mph. The governor said it will bring “unimaginable devastation” to the state and the National Weather Service has warned some locations may be uninhabitable for weeks or months after the devastating storm. (📷: AP)

Corey Lewis was finishing up lunch with two kids he was taking care of when a white woman came up to ask “if the kids were alright.” She left briefly before returning to ask if the girl could get out of the car so the woman could ask if she knew who Lewis was. Lewis says when he said no, the woman got upset and threatened to call the cops. Lewis says she then followed his car to the gas station and into his neighborhood, where he went on Facebook Live to record the incident in disbelief. In the video, Lewis can be heard explaining the situation to police, who confirmed they received a call about “suspicious behavior.” “All because I got two kids in the backseat who do not look like me…. It’s crazy,” Lewis said. (📷: Lewis)

Florida governor Rick Scott said “this is the worst storm the Florida Panhandle has seen in over 100 years” and that for many parts of the coast, “the time to evacuate has come and gone.” Hurricane Michael is expected to make landfall late Wednesday morning or early afternoon. It’s expected to be life-threatening and bring storm surges of up to 14 feet along the Panhandle, Big Ben, and Nature Coast. (📷: Handout/Reuters)
Check out all the 🔥 red carpet looks from the 2018 #AMAs 🎶🏆 (📷: Getty Images)

Samira Wiley, best known to "Orange Is the New Black" fans as Poussey Washington, said during an interview with WYNC that she “cried a lot” when she was accidentally outed by a former costar. Wiley said she always thought of her “OITNB” character as being queer, even though she wasn’t comfortable disclosing her own sexuality. Eventually, Wiley came out publicly, and even married a writer on “OITNB,” last year: “Everyone’s journey is their own, you should be able to come out on your own terms,” Wiley said 👩‍❤️‍💋‍👩 💓 Follow @buzzfeedlgbt for more 🏳️‍🌈 news. (📸: Netflix, Getty Images)

Busy Philipps wrote in an upcoming memoir that James Franco threw her to the ground while the two were filming “Freaks and Geeks" in 1999. Philipps wrote that after she was instructed to hit Franco in the chest during a scene, "he grabbed both my arms and screamed in my face, ‘DON’T EVER TOUCH ME AGAIN!'” “And he threw me to the ground. Flat on my back. Wind knocked out of me.” Philipps, who played the role of Kim Kelly on the cult classic TV show, said Franco, who played Daniel Desario, apologized to her the next day at the direction of the show’s producers and director, but there were never any consequences for his behavior. This past January, Franco was accused of sexual misconduct by five women. (📸: Getty)

Rose’s Batwoman will be introduced into the CW’s “Arrowverse” on December 9. The network described the character as, “an out lesbian and highly trained street fighter primed to snuff out the failing city’s criminal resurgence” when announcing Rose’s casting. “This is something I would have died to have seen on TV when I was a young member of the LGBT community who never felt represented on tv and felt alone and different,” Rose said at the time. Follow @buzzfeedlgbt for more 🌈🦇💥 (📸: The CW/Getty Images)

“She’s done a fantastic job and we’ve done a fantastic job together,” Trump told reporters shortly after her departure was announced. A Western diplomat told BuzzFeed News that he was “surprised” by the potential Haley resignation and that Haley did not brief his office about her move. (📸: Getty Images)

White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders said the two will discuss manufacturing resurgence, prison reform, how to prevent gang violence, and what can be done to reduce violence in Chicago. (📸: Getty Images)

Vote.org says 65,000 people registered to vote in the 24 hours after Taylor Swift encouraged her 112 million Instagram followers to register. For context, 190,178 new voters were registered nationwide in the entire month of September, while 56,669 were registered in August 🗳 (📸: Getty Images)

Google is shutting down its long-overlooked social network Google+ after a software glitch exposed the personal information of up to 500,000 users. The tech giant reportedly discovered the glitch in March 2018 but did not disclose it until now, in an attempt to avoid regulatory scrutiny and damage to its reputation 💻🚫 (📷: Getty Images)

Amy Steenburg was turning 30, and her sisters, husband, and friends planned a surprise: a limo to take the close-knit group to a craft brewery an hour from their upstate New York homes. They’d been on the road for about 30 minutes when the limo got into a "high-energy" crash, authorities said. Everyone in the limo, including the driver, was killed, along with two pedestrians. The cause of the crash has not yet been determined. (📷: Facebook)

Hurricane Michael could become a Category 3 storm as it threatens to slam Florida as early as Wednesday, bringing dangerous storm surges and winds. Florida Gov. Rick Scott declared a state of emergency for the Florida Panhandle and surrounding regions on Sunday, and extended the emergency declaration on Monday. “We know that a storm like Michael can be devastating and deadly,” he warned.(📷: NOAA)

Hundreds of dogs and their humans took to the streets of London in protest of the British exit from the European Union and called for a second “Wooferendum” 🐕✊ 🇪🇺 Follow @world for more headlines from across the 🌏 (📸: Getty Images)

Jodie Whittaker is the first woman to play the Doctor in the show’s 55-year history. People are loving her first full episode in the role, which was capped with a speech about how “we can evolve while staying true to who we are.” 👏👽📺 (📸: BBC)

The device, called Facebook Portal, allows people to make video calls through Facebook Messenger by saying “Hey Portal.” The device includes Amazon Alexa and has a camera with the ability to track people as they move. Portal costs $199 with a larger model priced at $349. (📸: Facebook)

Marion Stanford of Hamilton, Texas, told @dallasnews that police visited her house and asked her about the sign, and then confiscated it. “Police told me to remove the sign or they would take it and would arrest me,” Stanford told the paper. “So I let them take the sign.” The city manager has denied police seized the sign, saying Stanford gave it away. The sign is still at the police station, according to the Morning News. (📸: Sid Miller)

Taylor Swift got publicly political on Sunday, announcing for the first time her support for Democratic candidates and encouraging her fans to vote. “In the past I’ve been reluctant to publicly voice my political opinions, but due to several events in my life and in the world in the past two years, I feel very differently about that now," Swift wrote. She didn't mention Trump, but Swift, who has a home in Nashville, said she's opposing his pick for Senate in Tennessee, Marsha Blackburn 🗳 (📷:@taylorswift)

New York police said the Ford Expedition limousine failed to stop at an intersection and went across into a parking lot, striking another vehicle and two pedestrians. Both pedestrians and all 18 people in the limousine, including the driver, were killed. The intersection where the crash occurred reportedly "follows a long, steep incline." (📷: AP)
After Brett Kavanaugh was sworn in on Saturday, many people, including one college club and a senator, showed themselves drinking to celebrate the new justice, using #BeersForBrett.

On “SNL’s” Weekend Update, Davidson went in on the unplanned Trump-supporting monologue that Kanye gave at the end of last week’s show. Contradicting Kanye’s claim that the cast and crew had told him not to wear a “Make America Great Again” hat, Davidson said “nobody told him not to wear it … [but] I wish I bullied you. I wish I suggested, you know, it might upset some people, like, your wife or every black person ever, you know?” (📷: NBC)

Right after Russia’s Nurmagomedov forced Irish champion McGregor to tap out in the fourth round, the winning fighter leapt out of the octagon and headed straight for McGregor’s team where a fight ensued. Nurmagomedov has apologized, but said he was provoked by comments about his religion, country, and family. He was escorted out of the arena by police and his payment is being withheld while an investigation takes place. (📷: Getty)

At least 1,763 people are now confirmed to have died after a magnitude 7.5 earthquake and 10-foot tsunami hit the island of Sulawesi. Authorities say rescue efforts will come to an end on Thursday, two weeks after the disaster. (📷: Reuters)

Thousands protested the confirmation of Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, who faced multiple allegations of sexual misconduct. Kavanaugh was confirmed and sworn in Saturday by one of the narrowest Supreme Court confirmation votes in US history (📸: Getty, AP, Chris Geidner via Twitter)

Police received an anonymous tip about the incident, according to Hartford Public Schools. Police said the brownies were distributed in goody bags for football players as well as “used to obtain votes for the queen contest,” and that the aspiring homecoming queen/brownie baker left the state following the incident. (📷: Getty)

The Senate voted 50-48 to confirm Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court Saturday, the narrowest vote on a Supreme Court nomination in 137 years. The confirmation is a major victory for Republicans after sexual harassment allegations against Kavanaugh threatened to sink his nomination in recent weeks. His appointment could move the top court to the right for a generation. (📸: Reuters)

Multiple ethics complaints have been filed against Kavanaugh in his current court, the US Court of Appeals for the DC Circuit, about his testimony in recent weeks in the US Senate and his response to allegations of sexual misconduct. The chief judge of the circuit normally handles ethics cases, but they have discretion to step aside if they conclude “circumstances warrant disqualification,” under the federal judiciary’s rules. (📷: Reuters)

Moments after the auctioneer’s hammer went down, the artist’s iconic “Girl With The Red Balloon” began to shred itself through its frame in front of shocked onlookers. It was apparently triggered by a remote device. Banksy, who chooses to remain anonymous, appeared to confirm the hoax on Instagram. (📷: @banksy)

Jim Bunner, a multimedia journalist for an NBC affiliate in Minnesota, was fired a day after he was spotted wearing a “Make America Great Again” hat while covering a Trump rally for the local TV station. His picture was taken by Mark Vancleave, a video journalist for Minnesota’s Star Tribune. “He violated our policy so he’s no longer with us,” Noel Sederstrom, news director for KTTC, told BuzzFeed News. “We don’t allow our people to wear campaign clothing while on assignment.” Prohibiting reporters from wearing campaign clothing or pins, especially while on the job, is standard practice across the news industry. (📸: Mark Vancleave/Star Tribune via AP)

Brett Kavanaugh will be confirmed to the United States Supreme Court – unless something shocking happens – after undecided senators Susan Collins, a Republican, and Joe Manchin, a Democrat, announced their support Friday. That gives Kavanaugh, who has been accused of sexual assault by multiple women, the support of 51 senators — 50 Republicans and Manchin, the Democratic senator from West Virginia. Republican Sen. Lisa Murkowski announced earlier in the day she will oppose Kavanaugh’s nomination because she fears it will hurt the public’s faith in the courts. The Senate can move to a final vote on Kavanaugh’s nomination as early as Saturday. (📸: Reuters)
Sorrentino, 37, pleaded guilty to tax evasion in January. He will also serve two years of probation. (📷: Getty)

Jason Van Dyke has been found guilty of second-degree murder. A dashcam video taken in 2014 showed Van Dyke opening fire within seconds of coming out of the patrol car and continuing to shoot at 17-year-old McDonald as he’s seen lying on the ground. The video captured the teen holding a knife, but he appeared to be moving away from officers as Van Dyke began shooting. The shooting set off waves of protests for nearly four years. (📷: Getty/Family handout)

57 people in 16 states have gotten sick from salmonella-linked raw beef supplied by JBS Tolleson, an Arizona-based meat company, according to the Food Safety and Inspection Service. If you have beef products packaged between July 26 to Sept. 7 sold under the following brand names: Cedar River Farms, Gourmet Burger, JBS Generic, Grass Run Farms Natural Beef, Showcase, and Showcase/Walmart, you should throw it out or return it to the store. (📷: Getty)

Senator Republicans just narrowly voted to end debate on Kavanaugh’s nomination and move forward with the final vote. Unless two senators change their position at the last minute, he will be confirmed. (📷: Reuters)
